city clerktreasurer preface this a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the city of portage indiana source materials used in the preparation of the the 1985 ordinances subsequently adopted by the common council the source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof the absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this the reader can locate any section of the 1985 any subsequent ordinance included herein the chapters of the been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage notes which tie related sections of the which refer to relevant state law have been included a table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the included at the back of this system the chapter and section numbering system used in this the same system used in many state and local government codes each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash the figure before the dash refers to the chapter number and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter thus the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 12 and the first section of chapter 6 is 61 under this system each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments for example if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 61 and 62 is desired to be added such new section would be numbered 615 new articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or in the case of articles may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject and in the case of divisions may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject the next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division new chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters page numbering system the page numbering system used in this a prefix system the letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume the number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion in the case of a chapter of the the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter in the case of an appendix to the the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix the following are typical parts of codes of ordinances which may or may not appear in this this time and their corresponding prefixes code cd code appendix cda1 code comparative tables cct1 state law reference table slt1 code index cdi1 index the index has been prepared with the greatest of care each particular item has been placed under several headings some of which are couched in lay phraseology others in legal terminology and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees there are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested looseleaf supplements a special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication with this system the publication will be kept uptodate subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited and the affected page or pages will be reprinted these new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages keeping this publication uptodate at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication as revised pages are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions it is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and in addition that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes acknowledgments this publication was under the direct supervision of milton e lefkoff supervising editor and ronald mclaughlin editor of the municipal tallahassee florida credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publishers staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project the publisher is most grateful to mr felix c kimbrough city clerktreasurer and mr gregory a sobkowski city attorney for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication it is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the daytoday administration of the citys affairs municipal code example  state law reference codification of ordinances ic 36151 et seq  adoption of ordinances ic 364611364616 the provisions of this chapter will be the general provisions which will control the construction and use of all ordinances and this  unauthorized alterations it shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof or to alter or tamper with this any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby  definitions and rules of construction in the construction of this of all ordinances passed by the council the following definitions and rules shall be observed unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council city means the city of portage indiana or the area within the territorial limits of the city of portage indiana and such territory outside of the city over which the city has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional or statutory provision council or common council means the common council of the city of portage all its members or all councilmembers means the total number of councilmembers holding office county means the county of porter indiana gender means the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter genders ic means the indiana as now or hereafter amended law denotes applicable federal law the constitution and statutes of the state the ordinances of the city and when appropriate any and all rules and regulations which may be promulgated thereunder may is permissive month means a calendar month must and shall are each mandatory oath includes affirmation and the words swear and sworn shall be equivalent to the words affirm and affirmed officers etc means whenever any officer department board or commission is referred to by title such as clerktreasurer such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words of the city of portage owner applied to a building or land includes any part owner joint owner tenant in common joint tenant tenant by the entirety of the whole or a part of such building or land person includes an individual firm joint venture joint stock company partnership copartnership association club company corporation business trust estate governmental entity organization or any other legal entity or group acting as a unit or its legal representatives agents or assignees or the manager lessee servant officer or employee of any of them personal property includes money goods chattels things in action and evidence of debt preceding and following means the next before and next after respectively property includes real and personal property real property includes lands tenements and hereditaments sidewalk means the part of a street between the curb lines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of pedestrians singular and plural means the singular number shall include the plural and the plural shall include the singular state means the state of indiana street or highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part of the way is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel the term includes an alley in the city tenant and occupant applied to a building or land include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land whether alone or with others tense means that words used in the present tense include the past and the future tenses and vice versa unless manifestly inapplicable written and in writing include printing lithographing or other mode of representing words and letters year means a calendar year  126 state law reference definitions applicable to construction of statutes ic 1145  definitions applicable to motor vehicles ic 91321 et seq interpretation of language all words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning  catchlines of sections the catchlines of the several sections of this in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections nor as any part of the sections nor unless expressly so provided shall they be so deemed when any of such sections including the catchlines are amended or reenacted acts by agents when an act is required by provision of this an ordinance of this city the same being such that it may be done as well by an agent as by the principal such requirement shall be construed to include all such acts performed by an authorized agent  prohibited acts include causing and permitting whenever in this in the ordinances of the city any act or omission is made unlawful it shall include causing allowing permitting aiding abetting suffering or concealing the fact of such act or omission  computation of time except when otherwise specifically provided the time within which an act is required to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last day unless the last day is a sunday in which case it shall also be excluded  state law reference computation of time ic 341611 construction the provisions of this the ordinances of this city and all proceedings under them are to be construed with a view to effect their objectives and promote justice  effect of repeal of ordinances the repeal of any provision of this an ordinance of this city shall not repeal the repealing clause of an ordinance or revive any provision of this ordinance which has been repealed thereby  severability of parts of sections paragraphs sentences clauses and phrases of this hereby deemed to be severable  and if any phrase clause sentence paragraph or section of this its application to any persons or circumstances shall be declared unconstitutional invalid or unenforceable by a valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction such unconstitutionality invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases clauses sentences paragraphs or sections of this their application  common terms in accordance with the laws of the state and to give such laws full force and effect the following words or any variations thereof shall be understood and given the meaning indicated whenever such words fund  2163 rainy day fundcreated a creation of rainy day fund there is hereby established a rainy day fund to receive transfers of unused and unencumbered funds of the type specified in ic 361851 as amended from time to time b purpose of the fund the funds on deposit in the rainy day fund may be used for the operation of the city and its various departments when the city does not have sufficient levies or funds to pay such costs including but not limited to salaries and wages costs of services supplies equipment capital improvements repairs and similar expenditures or to make temporary loans to other city funds c transfer to fund the common council shall determine the amount if any of unused and unencumbered funds available to be transferred to the rainy day fund and shall make such transfers subject to the provisions set forth in ic 36185 and 361851 upon adoption of an ordinance approving said transfers d appropriations the common council may authorize the expenditure of funds from the rainy day fund by appropriations made in the same manner as other funds are appropriated that receive tax monies upon making a finding that the proposed use of the funds is consistent with the intent of the fund  2607 cross reference drain maintenance fund  2161  gift funds  2162  cumulative capital development fund  2163 vending machines placed on property owned by the city vending machines approved by the city board of works may be placed on property owned by the city any vending machine currently on city property must also be approved by the board of works in order to remain on said property including those vending machines in restricted areas failure to gain approval for a new or existing vending machine shall require removal of the machine and its contents from city property until such approval is granted any vending machine placed on city property must be governed by a written contract signed and executed by the appropriate governing body department head or administrator for the property on which the vending machine will be placed said contract must detail the procedure for maintaining the vending machine and the division of funds for both maintaining the machine and commissions all revenue generated and costs incurred in operating vending machines located on city property must be accounted for by the clerktreasurer and deposited into or paid out of the city general operating fund a vending machine may be placed in a restricted area a restricted area for this section means an area other than those available to the public the revenues from such a restricted vending machine may be restricted for the use and benefit of those employees who use said vending machine and generate the revenues all revenues and commissions received from a vending machine placed in an area where the public makes use of the machines and generates the resulting revenues shall be accounted for by the clerktreasurer and then deposited into the city general operating fund unless otherwise provided for herein the clerktreasurer shall disburse the previously accounted for funds into each departments account based on the location of the vending machine any board commission or department of the city with jurisdiction over property such as the city port authority may enter into contracts for the placement of vending machines on property under its jurisdiction so long as the contract complies with the requirements of this section said board or commission is authorized to retain any revenues and commissions from the placement of vending machines  approval of agreements a agreements shall be defined to include any written contract agreement memorandum of understanding pact or commitment including those of no monetary value entered into by a department of this city and any third party b all agreements shall be approved by the board of works prior to the full execution of the agreement except 1 the park and recreation board shall approve agreements entered into by the department of parks and recreation 2 the port authority board shall approve agreements entered into by the marina and port authority 3 the redevelopment commission shall approve agreements entered into by the department of redevelopment c upon approval by the board of works the park and recreation board the port authority board or the redevelopment commission a copy of the agreement shall be forwarded to the clerktreasurer who shall maintain a copy of each agreement d the common council may from time to time exempt certain agreements from the requirements of this section by resolution e any agreement under this section which has a total monetary cost to the city or any of its departments boards or subunits of $100000 or more shall be forwarded by the clerktreasurer to the common council at its next regular meeting immediately following the approval of the agreement  2717 secs 28 29  reserved americanmade products purchasing specifications a the specifications for the purchase of goods shall include a requirement that 1 unmanufactured articles materials and supplies have been mined or produced in the united states  2 manufactured articles materials and supplies except for vehicles have been manufactured in the united states substantially all from articles materials or supplies mined produced or manufactured in the united states 3 vehicles have been manufactured in north america from at least 75 percent of articles materials or supplies mined produced or manufactured in the united states b a shall not apply if 1 the purchase price of the goods is less than $500000  or 2 the purchasing agent finds and certifies in writing to the board of works that articles materials or supplies of sufficient and reasonable available commercial quantities and satisfactory quality are not available at a reasonable price the price of americanmade goods shall be generally considered reasonable if they are not six percent more than the cost of equivalent imported goods c every contract for any public work let by the city of portage or its boards or commissions in an amount greater than $5000000 shall contain a provision that in the performance of the work the contractor shall use only such unmanufactured articles materials and supplies as have been mined produced or manufactured in the united states substantially all from articles materials and supplies as have been mined produced or manufactured in the united states d c shall not apply if the purchasing agent finds and certifies in writing to the board of works prior to the award of the contract that in respect to some articles materials and supplies it is impractical to make such a requirement or that it would unreasonably increase the cost a cost increase of less than six percent shall be considered reasonable e if a contractor is found to be in violation of the requirements of subsection c and has not been relieved of that requirement by action of the purchasing agent pursuant to subsection d prior to award of the contract the purchasing agent shall make public the violation and the contractor shall not be eligible for award of another public works contract from the city for a period of three years notice of this consequence shall be made a provision of all public works contracts of the city  9517 secs 211225  reserved article ii  common council division 1  generally conflict of interest no councilmember shall directly or indirectly be financially interested in any contract or agreement with the city for any matter cause or thing by which liability or indebtedness is created against the city no member shall purchase any bond order claim or demand whatever against the city for less than the sum of the amounts specified therein b attendance voting every councilmember shall be present within the council room during the sitting of the council unless excused or necessarily prevented and shall vote on each question put unless he has a personal or pecuniary interest in such question  enactment procedure for ordinances a all ordinances shall be read two times before final passage unless the rules are suspended b no ordinance may be passed at the same meeting in which it is introduced unless under suspension of rules and then only in case there are present and voting at least twothirds of all the members elect of the council c a majority vote of all the members of the common council elected or appointed is required to pass an ordinance unless a greater vote is required by statute d subsections a and b shall not apply to ordinances described in ic 363412b and c    7202 state law reference passage of ordinance requires majority vote ic 364612 secs 229240  reserved division 2  meetings regular time place the regular stated and fixed meetings of the common council of the city shall be held at the council chamber on the first tuesday of each month at a time designated by the council    8503 state law reference regular meetings ic 36467a special a the call of a special meeting shall be in writing and specify therein the particular purpose for which such meeting is called such call shall be signed by the mayor when made by him and when made by the council by them and sealed with the seal of the city and countersigned by the clerktreasurer b certified copies of the call of a special meeting shall be personally served by the chief of police or his deputy if practicable upon every member entitled to be present at such special meeting no business shall be transacted at such special meeting unless the subject thereof is named in the call the minute sheet shall show the issuance of the call and the service of such notice for which purpose the chief of police or his deputy shall return copies of such notices to the clerktreasurer at such special meeting written notice and the return thereof shall be waived by the presence of all councilmembers at such specially called meeting c special meetings may be called in the manner provided in this section by four councilmembers in case the mayor is unable or refuses to call such meeting and the call in such cases shall state the mayors inability or refusal  state law reference special meetings ic 36467b quorum four councilmembers shall constitute a quorum  but a smaller number may meet adjourn from time to time and compel the attendance of members  state law reference quorum ic 364610 order of business the following shall be the order of business at all regular meetings of the common council 1 at the hour appointed for the meeting the mayor shall call the meeting to order if the mayor is not present at such meeting the president pro tempore shall take the chair and call the meeting to order and preside as chairman of the meeting if neither the mayor nor president pro tempore shall be present at such meeting the council shall proceed to elect from among its members a temporary chairman to preside as chairman of that meeting 2 the clerktreasurer or in his absence a member of the common council appointed by the mayor shall proceed to call the roll of the members and mark the absentees if any and announce whether a quorum is present 3 the reading or suspending the reading of the minutes of the previous meeting or meetings of the council and the approval or amendment of the same 4 clerktreasurers report unfinished or deferred business  11 new business  12 reception of petitions memorials and remonstrances  and 13 adjournment  state law reference presiding officer ic 36468 rules of procedure the council may adopt rules of procedure to govern the conduct of its meetings    12616 duties of mayor a the mayor shall take the chair for the opening of the meeting he shall immediately call the council to order and on the appearance of a quorum shall proceed with the order of business stated all questions relating to the priority of business shall be decided by the presiding officer subject to the approval of the council the presiding officer shall have the right to call a recess at any time b the mayor shall preserve order and decorum may speak to points of order in preference to members rising from his seat for that purpose and shall decide questions of order subject to an appeal by any member on which appeal no member shall speak more than twice unless by leave of the standing committees enumerated the following shall be the four standing committees of the common council 1 budget and finance 2 3 ways and means 4 strategic planning each standing committee shall consist of three members appointed by the president of the common council the president of the common council shall also appoint a chairperson of each committee from its respective membership the president of the common council shall be an exofficio member of each standing committee and may attend its meetings and participate in its deliberations the president of the common council shall not be entitled to vote in his capacity as an exofficio member of a standing committee  5101 duties of standing committees a the budget and finance committee shall make recommendations to the common council concerning 1 the annual city operating budget  2 the annual city employee salary budget  3 the annual elected officials salary budget  4 revisions to salaries andor staffing levels  and 5 the actual expenditures made from all city accounts b the ordinance committee shall 1 initiate the preparation of general ordinances relating to the governance of the city and special ordinances pertaining to special matters  and 2 review zoning and appropriation ordinances and ordinances amending the municipal code at the discretion of the chairperson c the ways and means committee shall make recommendations to the common council concerning 1 the initiation of general obligation andor revenue bonds  2 the establishment andor revision of fees  3 the establishment andor revision of local tax levies  and 4 other matters which may affect the revenue afforded the city such as tax abatement and other financial incentives d the strategic planning committee shall 1 identify and plan for the longterm capital needs of the city including but not limited to a health safety and service facilities including planning for sidewalk location road paving and general beautification projects  b rolling stock and equipment  c systems networks and related hardware and software  and d different methodologies for service provision  and 2 review proposals andor requests for annexation  5101 operation of the standing committees it shall be the obligation of all common council standing committees to consider all matters referred to it as provided in these rules and to make recommendations to the common council concerning those matters a standing committee may consider any other matter properly concerning departments or subject matter indicated by the name of the standing committee a standing committee may hear such testimony or public comment as the committee deems proper in lieu of separate hearings standing committees may meet with boards of corresponding city departments andor department heads or employees all standing committees shall meet in a fashion consistent with all prevailing opendoor meeting notice requirements and with a frequency sufficient to meet the responsibilities outlined in this division standing committees shall meet on call of its chairperson or any two of its members the clerktreasurer who shall maintain a record of such notices shall communicate notice a simple majority shall constitute a quorum which shall be necessary to conduct the business of the committee the chairperson may act as secretary or the committee may appoint a secretary who shall keep a memorandum of the proceedings and recommendations made during the meeting in standing committee meetings roberts rules of order shall be relaxed in order to encourage discussion but general procedural decorum shall prevail all standing committees shall establish and maintain an open ongoing dialogue with the mayor clerktreasurer and department heads regarding committee business  5101 appointment of special committees the mayor shall appoint all special committees which may be ordered by the council from time to time and the mayor shall designate the chairperson of each such special committee from the membership of the committee  5101 meetings any member of the common council shall be entitled to attend and participate in the discussions before any committee the common council member introducing any proposal referred to a committee shall be a member of that committee while it is considering that proposal but such common council member shall not be entitled to vote or be counted in determining a quorum  5101 standing committee action and reports all standing committees except the ordinance committee shall report to the common council upon each matter referred to it within fortyfive days of the referral should the president of the council withdraw or reassign the proposal this rule shall not apply after any hearing by a standing committee upon a proposal the committee chairperson shall submit a report either written or verbal to the common council  5101 all ordinances amending the municipal code may be submitted to the ordinance committee for review prior to consideration at a city council meeting after reviewing an ordinance submitted to it pursuant to this section the committee shall place the ordinance on the agenda for an upcoming city council meeting with a favorable recommendation or no recommendation the committee shall complete its review and place an ordinance on the agenda for a city council meeting within one hundred twenty days of the date the ordinance is referred to the committee  5101 dissolution a special committee when its report if made is disposed of and it has no other business stands inches tall horizontally across the back window of the vehicle e in order to be eligible for assignment of a takehome vehicle an employee must live within the corporate limits an exception to this is construction projects a policy statement it is the policy of the city of portage to provide for the negotiation of mutually acceptable project labor agreements with local labor unions representing experienced and skilled construction workers covering public construction alteration or repair work b project labor agreements 1 all solicitations for bids issued by the city shall except as otherwise provided herein include the following language each successful bidder and any and all levels of subcontractors regardless of tier as a condition of being awarded a contract or subcontract will agree to abide by the provisions of the insert name of project project labor agreement as executed and effective by and between the project manager andor construction manager authorized to negotiate and enter into such a project labor agreement on behalf of the city of portage and the local labor unions representing experienced and skilled construction workers and will be bound by the provisions of that agreement in the same manner as any other provision of the contract 2 any instructions to bidders or like document issued for a public works project by the city shall except as otherwise provided herein include the following language the general contract and all independent subcontracts ie subcontracts not included within a general contract and regardless of tier will be awarded to the lowest responsible and responsive bidder complying with the conditions and requirements provided in these instructions the bid forms and the other bid documents a responsible and responsive bidder is a bidder demonstrably possessing the skill ability and integrity necessary to faithfully perform the work called for by the contract based upon a determination of competent workmanship in accordance with indiana or any successor statute an eligible bidder is a bidder who is not debarred from bidding under any applicable law and which shall certify that it is able to furnish labor that can work in harmony with all other elements of labor employed or to be employed on the project in the interests of such harmony the longterm supply of skilled labor and to provide a legally enforceable means of assuring labor stability and labor peace over the life of the project each successful bidder and any and all levels of subcontractors regardless of tier as a condition of being awarded a contract or subcontract shall be required to enter into a project labor agreement for the insert name of project project with local labor unions representing experienced and skilled construction workers for the development and construction of the project and will be bound by the provisions of that project labor agreement in the same manner as any other provision of the contract c exception to use of project labor agreements project labor agreements shall not be required for professional services provided for a city project there may be additional circumstances there the benefits of proceeding without a project labor agreement may substantially exceed the benefits of proceeding with such an agreement in that case the specific department involved in such project shall prepare and submit a written report to the common council based on that report the common council shall determine whether to proceed without such an agreement d enforcement the common council retains its inherent authority to adopt means to enforce compliance by any contractor or subcontractor regardless of tier with the provisions of any project labor agreement entered into on behalf of the city  2299 authorized methods payments of the same type c if the city incurs any charge for the use of any type of financial instrument set forth above the city may collect a sum equal to the amount of the charge from the person et seq creation of fund there is hereby created a cumulative liability and physical damage reserve fund the fund the fund shall be nonreverting it shall be used for the purposes and in the manner set forth in this division and it shall be funded by appropriations or reappropriations made by the common council in such amounts and at such times as are necessary to meet the purposes of the fund and to otherwise comply with the provisions of this division  6287 purposes of fund a the fund shall be used only in connection with comprehensive general liability and physical damage claims anticipated or asserted against the city or against any employees or elected or appointed officials of the city against whom claims are asserted so long as such claims arise within the scope of city employment or from the performance of duties as such employees or elected or appointed officials b subject to the provisions of subsection a of this section the fund shall be used for the following purposes 1 to pay any claim so long as the same has been approved as required by this division or has been reduced to final judgment against the city  2 to pay the expenses of investigation of any claim  3 to pay expenses of litigation associated with any claim  4 to pay the costs and expenses of any seminars including reasonable transportation meals and lodging other instructional courses literature and dues and membership fees associated with questions of city liability  and 5 to pay the expenses of independent adjusters employed by the city including persons engaged to consult on loss management techniques and internal loss controls 6 to pay for the cost of liability insurance policies c notwithstanding any other provisions in this division to the contrary the fund shall not be used to replace or repair any city buildings including contents or city street lights and traffic signals or to pay any city workers compensation claims d notwithstanding any other provision in this division to the contrary funds accumulated in the city cumulative liability and physical damage reserve fund may be transferred to the city health insurance fund money may be transferred under the authority of this subsection only after the mayor issues a declaration that the health insurance fund is in immediate financial danger which requires a transfer of money no such transfer shall deplete the cumulative liability and physical damage reserve fund below the amount necessary to cover reserves for losses and other anticipated administrative expenses during the year in which the transfer is there is hereby created and established an ethics commission consisting of five members who do not hold a position of employment in any agency and who are not declared candidates for elected nonparty public office or elected officials b appointment of members and chairperson the mayor of the city shall appoint two members of the commission the common council shall appoint three members to the commission one of whom shall be an attorney licensed to practice law in the state of indiana an attorney appointed hereunder shall either be a resident of the city or maintain an office in the city all other members shall be residents of the city all members shall have never been convicted of a misdemeanor or felony 1 the common council and the mayor shall each appoint not less than one member of the commission who shall be a member of the opposite political party of the majority of the council initially one appointment by both the common council and the mayor shall serve for a term of one year the other appointments shall serve for a term of two years thereafter all terms shall expire after two years each appointee shall serve at the pleasure of the appointing authority until his or her successor is duly appointed and qualified vacancies shall be filled by the appointing authority which appointed the member creating the vacancy a member appointed to fill a vacancy shall serve for the duration of the unexpired term c general authority of the ethics commission the ethics commission shall have the powers and responsibilities 1 to adopt amend and rescind rules and regulations in furtherance of the operation of the commission 2 to make recommendations to the city council for amendments to this article and for such other legislation affecting the subject matter of this article as the ethics commission may deem necessary or desireable 3 to provide a continuing program of educational assistance and information regarding ethical conduct of all officials and consultants 4 to annually review statements of economic interest filed pursuant to section 2177 d investigations upon request by the mayor an official or employee a member of the ethics commission or any member of the city council the commission may hold hearings to investigate possible violations of this article and if the commission finds that a violation of this article has occurred it may recommend to the mayor or appropriate official a resolution of the violation or public disclosure of the violation or disciplinary action which may include dismissal  7594   10196 economic interest disclosure exceptions to disqualification from acting on city business any official shall disqualify himself or herself and refuse to act on any matter in which such official a dependent of the official or the private employer of the official has an economic interest or might derive a profit and upon which the official would be entitled to act in the discharge of his or her official duties the participation of an official does not violate this section by discussion or voting at a meeting if 1 disqualification of the official leaves the governing body of the agency with less than a quorum and 2 the official makes a disclosure under section 2177 of this article b improperly using official position 1 no official shall knowingly use or permit the use of any individual funds or property under his or her official control direction or custody or any funds or property of an agency for a purpose which is for the private benefit to the official or any other person nothing shall prevent the private use of property of an agency which is available on equal terms to the public generally such as library books or tennis courts or the use of property of an agency in accordance with municipal policy in the conduct of official business such as the use of automobiles of an agency or the use of offduty equipment by law enforcement officers if allowed by the rules of the respective department if in fact the property is used appropriately 2 an official shall not advocate or cause the employment appointment promotion transfer or advancement of a dependent or business associate to a position in the city an official shall not participate in an action relating to the employment or discipline of a dependent or business associate c improper influence no official except in the course of official duties shall assist any person in any transaction with an agency when such officials assistance is enhanced by that officialss position with an agency the subsection shall not apply either to an official applying on his own behalf or representing himself as to any matter in which he has an economic interest if not otherwise prohibited by law d prohibition of certain financial interest no official regardless of prior disclosure thereof who has an ownership or equity interest personally or dependent in any business entity doing or seeking to do business with any agency shall knowingly influence or attempt to influence the selection of or the conduct of business with such business entity by any agency e gifts or loans prohibited no official shall solicit or receive anything of monetary value from any person when it has been solicited received or given with the intent to give or obtain special consideration or influence as to any action by such official in his or her official capacity nothing shall prohibit contributions including political contributions which are reported in accordance with applicable law or which are accepted on behalf of any agency or an honorarium travel or other expenses reimbursed to any official as a result of a speaking engagement or personal appearance made as a result of that individuals official position f gifts or honoraria prohibited no official shall accept gifts or honoraria including such received by his or her dependents that exceed an aggregate value of $50000 in any twelve consecutive months from an individual business entity and all subsidiaries thereof that is doing business with the agency or is in the process of bidding for a contract with an agency in which the official holds an office or position g disclosure of privileged information no official shall disclose or use any information gained by reason of his or her official position for the immediate or anticipated personal gain or benefit of the official or any other person however nothing shall prohibit the disclosure or use of information which is a matter of public knowledge or which is available to the public on request h prohibition of certain appointments no dependent of an official may be appointed as a member of a city board or commission  7594   8696 complaints investigations hearings and appeals a any person with personal knowledge may file a compliant alleging a violation of this article if such complaint is filed by a member of the ethics commission such member is then disqualified from participating in any proceedings that may arise from the complaint 1 the complaint shall be in writing and signed under the penalties of perjury by the affiant the complaint shall state the nature of the alleged violations the dates time and place of each occurrence and name of the persons charged with the violations the complaint shall be filed with the secretary of the commission the mayor the president of the city council and the person at whom the complaint is directed the complainant shall also provide copies of any and all relevant documents to substantiate the allegations set forth 2 all complaints shall remain confidential when a complaint reaches public hearing before the commission the complaint and all records pertaining thereto shall become public records 3 within 30 days after receipt of a complaint the commission shall conduct a preliminary investigation the commission may extend the time for the completion of such preliminary investigation if it determines that such extension is necessary or desirable and would not be prejudicial to the person charged with the violation if the commission determines that the preliminary investigation must be completed in less than 30 days in order to avoid prejudice or irreparable harm to the person charged with the violation the commission shall complete the preliminary investigation in a shorter period of time 4 if the commission determines after preliminary investigation that there are no reasonable grounds to believe that a violation has occurred the commission shall dismiss the complaint if the commission dismisses the complaint it shall do so in writing setting forth the facts and the provisions of law upon which the dismissal is based and provide copies of the written dismissal to the complainant to the person charged with the violation to the mayor and to the president of the city council the record shall remain confidential unless the person against whom the complaint was made requests disclosure 5 if after preliminary investigation the commission does not dismiss the complaint the commission shall schedule the matter for hearing within 30 days and the accused shall be given the opportunity to attend the matter may be resolved at a prehearing conference between the commission and the person charged with the violation 6 all hearings that are held to determine whether the provisions of this article have been violated shall be conducted in conformance with the rules and regulations of the commission b the right to appeal decisions made by the commission shall be as follows 1 if an official objects to the findings of the commission he shall within 15 days of notice thereof file a notice of objection to the commissions findings the official shall set forth specifically his objections and set forth specifically his request for relief that notice shall be delivered to the office of the secretary of the commission 2 within ten days of the delivery of notice the commission shall meet to consider the officials objections the commission shall either affirm its original decision amend its decision or reverse its decision based upon the request 3 if the official objects to the commissions decision the official may appeal the commissions decision to the porter circuit or superior court 4 the standard of review shall be the same as the standard for reviewing all administrative decisions in the state of indiana  7594 enforcement a any official or consultant who knowingly fails to file a statement of economic interest when required by section 2177 shall be subject to a fine of $2500 for each 30 days the statement is delinquent the commission shall have the discretion to waive any fine imposed by this section b failure of any official candidate or consultant to file a statement may also result in the commission reporting such failure to the appropriate supervisory or appointment authority and may be cause for suspension discharge removal from office or other such disciplinary action as may by the appropriate authority be deemed necessary and proper c a violation of this article may be cause for suspension discharge removal from office or such other disciplinary action as may by the appropriate authority be deemed necessary and proper and consistent with personnel ordinances and rules a written response outlining any action taken as a result of a recommendation of the ethics commission shall be made within 14 calendar days after receipt of the written recommendation this section shall not derogate from employee rights under any collective bargaining agreement or personnel ordinance or rule promulgated thereunto if the appropriate authority determines that the written response required in this section cannot be made within 14 calendar days after receipt of the recommendation because of procedures prescribed under any collective bargaining agreement personnel ordinance or rule promulgated thereunto the appropriate authority shall so report within 14 days after receipt of the recommendation stating the date on which the written response will be submitted to the ethics commission upon receipt of the written response or in the event no response is received the ethics definitions city means the city of portage indiana direct line of supervision means an elected officer or employee who is in a position to affect the terms and conditions of another individuals employment including making decisions about work assignments compensation grievances advancement or performance evaluation the term does not include the responsibilities of the executive legislative body or fiscal body of the city as provided by law to make decisions regarding salary ordinances budgets or personnel policies of the city elected official means the executive or a member of the executive body of the city  a member of the legislative body of the city  or a member of the fiscal body of the city employed means an individual who is employed by the city on a fulltime parttime temporary intermittent or hourly basis the term does not include an individual who holds only an elected office the term includes an individual who is a party to an employment contract with the city member of the fire department means the fire chief or a firefighter appointed to the department member of the police department means the police chief or a police officer appointed to the department relative means any of the following 1 a spouse  2 a parent or stepparent  3 a child or stepchild  4 a brother sister stepbrother or stepsister  5 a niece or nephew  6 an aunt or uncle  or 7 a daughterinlaw or soninlaw an adopted child of an individual is treated as a natural child of the individual the terms brother and sister include a brother or sister by the half blood  7312 employment of relatives a individuals who are relatives may not be employed by the city in a position that results in one relative being in the direct line of supervision of the other relative b with regard to an individual who is employed by the city on the date the individuals relative begins serving a term of an elected office of the city may remain employed by the city and maintain the individuals position or rank even if the individuals employment would violate the prohibition against a relative being in the direct line of supervision of the other relative c an individual described in subsection b above shall not be promoted to a position or in the case of an individual who is a member of a merit police department or merit fire department be promoted to a position that is not within the merit ranks  if the new position would violate the prohibition against one relative being in the direct line of supervision of the other relative  7312 exclusions from section 2192 a an followed by an immediate reemployment by the city without loss of payroll time b this chapter does not abrogate or affect an employment contract with the city that 1 an individual is a party to  and 2 preserve those records in accordance with state statute whenever possible  10218 human rights article i  purpose statement of purpose the city of portage wishes to enshrine the values of its diversity as a strength and appreciates the culture and history of its various communities of people including immigrant communities in the municipal the city of portage as a permanent testament  12318 commitment to the support of human rights the city of portage recognizes that the united states constitution and its amendments particularly the bill of rights guarantee fundamental human rights and civil liberties for the residents of portage the city welcomes individuals of diverse racial ethnic religious and national backgrounds and we recognize that our diversity is critical to the economic cultural and social progression of our region the city is committed to upholding the human rights of all persons in portage including united states citizens and citizens of other nations and the free exercise and enjoyment of any and all rights and privileges secured by the constitutions of the united states of america and the state of indiana the city calls upon all city officials and employees to respect the human rights and civil liberties of all members of this community and eliminate discrimination based on race ethnicity national origin religion sexual orientation gender identity age disability and veteran status likewise the city calls upon all private citizens including residents employers educators and business owners to demonstrate similar respect for human rights and civil liberties and eliminate discrimination based on race ethnicity national origin religion sexual orientation gender identity age disability and veteran status the city commits to working collaboratively with elected officials city leadership business owners church leaders educators and residents to create a safe welcoming equitable and inclusive city for everyone  12318 periodic review the common council of the city of portage shall review the issue of human rights within the city from time to time and take action as may be deemed appropriate the uphold the commitment of this chapter  12318 36826 article i  in general secs 1011025  reserved article ii  animal control division 1  generally definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning abandon means to desert an animal or to leave the animal permanently in a place without making provision for adequate longterm care of the animal this term does not include leaving an animal in a place that is temporarily vacated for the protection of human life during a disaster animal means any living vertebrate domestic or wild not including man animal shelter means any facility operated by the humane society or municipal agency or its authorized agents for the purpose of impounding or caring for animals held under the authority of this article or state law at large means any animal which is not confined in a pen completely fenced in yard cage house or other secure enclosure without means of escape or is not secured by a leash or a lead under the control of its owner or a responsible person beat means to unnecessarily or cruelly strike an animal or to throw the animal against an object causing the animal to suffer severe pain or injury the term does not include reasonable training or disciplinary techniques bite means the seizure with the teeth or jaws of an animal so that the skin of the human being or animal seized has been pierced lacerated or has received any break or abrasion of the skin board means the board of public works and safety of the city bodily injury means any injury to the body including physical pain confined means the restriction of an animal at all times by the owner in a pen completely fencedin yard cage house or other secure enclosure without means of escape dangerous animal means an animal meeting any of the following criteria 1 any animal which bites and inflicts serious bodily injury on any person or animal without provocation on any public property or in any place outside or over the boundaries of its owners property  or 2 any animal which without provocation and while on its owners property bites and inflicts bodily injury on any person or animal where the victim was acting peaceably was not provoking the animal and was not committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises or otherwise had a legal right to be on said property at the time of the bite or attack  or 3 any animal which on more than one occasion without provocation bites and inflicts bodily injury upon any person or animal on any public property or in any place outside or over the boundaries of its owners property  or 4 any animal owned or harbored primarily for the purpose of dog or other animal fighting and has for this purpose become a threat to the safety of other animals and persons dangerous animal does not include law enforcement animals owned by any government agency working within the scope and course of its duties dog means companionship such as a dog or cat domestic livestock means any animal other than a domestic pet that is kept for commercial purposes or is a member of but is not limited to one or more of the noncommercial establishment harboring four or more animals excluding farm animals birds or fish leash or lead means a cord rope strap or chain which shall be securely fastened to the collar or harness of a dog or other animal and which shall be of sufficient strength to keep such dog or other animal under control neglect means endangering an animals health by failing to provide or arrange to provide the animal with food or water if the animal is dependent upon the person for the provision of food or water  restraining an animal for more than a brief period in a manner that seriously endangers the animals life or health  restraining the animal in a manner that seriously endangers the animals life or health  failing to provide reasonable care  or leaving a domestic pet or livestock the purpose of this article is to provide harmonious relationships in the interaction between man and animal by 1 protecting the citizens of the city from rabies by specifying such preventive and control measures as may be necessary  2 providing peace and security to residents from annoyance intimidation and injury from dogs and other animals  3 protecting animals from improper use abuse neglect inhumane treatment and health hazards and particularly rabies  4 encouraging responsible pet ownership  and 5 providing for the assessment of penalties for violators and for the enforcement and administration of this article  enforcement the provisions of this article shall be enforced by the animal warden or deputy animal warden and in their absence or unavailability by the police department or any other law enforcement officer  314 penalties a each day the terms of this article are violated shall constitute a distinct and separate offense b a person found to be violating any satisfactory correction thereof c except as otherwise provided in this article any person who shall continue any violation of this article beyond the time limit provided for in such written notice or second offense the fine shall not be less than $5000 nor more than $20000  and 3 for the third or any subsequent offense the fine shall not be less than $10000 nor more than $250000  animal warden a rabies vaccination a it shall be unlawful for any person to own possess harbor or keep any dog cat or ferret over the age of three months which is not currently immunized against rabies the inability of the owner to provide a current valid rabies vaccination certificate shall constitute prima facie evidence that the dog cat or ferret is not currently immunized against rabies b no person who owns keeps possesses harbors or has custody of a dog cat or ferret which is over the age of three months and is not currently immunized against rabies shall allow such dog cat or ferret to run at large c the rabies vaccination of a dog cat or ferret shall be maintained by ongoing revaccination of the animal as follows 1 ferrets shall be revaccinated within 12 months of the prior vaccination 2 dogs and cats that are vaccinated with a rabies vaccine whose label recommends annual boosters shall be revaccinated within 12 months of the prior vaccination 3 dogs and cats that are vaccinated with a rabies vaccine whose label recommends a booster one year later and triennially thereafter shall be revaccinated within 12 months of the first vaccination and shall be revaccinated within 36 months of each vaccination thereafter a c   8707 animal bites a it shall be unlawful for anyone knowing that a person or animal has been bitten by another animal to fail to immediately notify the animal warden deputy animal warden or police department of such bite b it shall be the duty and responsibility of the owner of any animal which has bitten any other animal or person to immediately notify the animal warden or police department of such bite and to immediately confine such animal c the owner of any such animal which has bitten any other animal or person shall on demand of the animal warden deputy animal warden or police officer surrender such animal for rabies observation for a period of ten days unless 1 the owner of such biting animal presents proof of a current rabies immunization the animal warden may in his discretion allow the biting animal to be confined on the premises of its owner under the observation of a licensed veterinarian for a period of ten days in such a manner which will prohibit it from biting any person or animal  and 2 the owner of a biting animal under home confinement shall be required to furnish evidence of examination by a licensed veterinarian of the biting animal on the first fifth and tenth day of such home confinement all at the cost of the owner d if any owner of any biting animal fails or refuses to immediately surrender such animal for rabies observation the animal warden deputy animal warden police officer or other law enforcement officer is hereby empowered to take all reasonable means to seize and impound such animal including the power to enter upon private property to do so but not to enter a private home without legal process e any biting animal surrendered or impounded for rabies observation shall be kept by the animal warden in an animal shelter designated by the board for a period of ten days the cost of which shall be paid by the owner of such biting animal f if such biting animal is not found to be infected with rabies at the expiration of the period for observation for rabies the animal shall be returned to the owner upon payment of the costs of the keep of such animal during such period of observation including any fee for veterinary services attributed to the bite g when an animal confined for biting shows signs of rabies or acts in a manner which would lead a person to believe that the animal may have rabies the owner veterinarian or animal shelter personnel shall immediately notify by telephone or in person the animal warden and the person bitten or the physician attending the bitten person and a responsible health agency as soon as he receives notice of such signs h if such biting animal is determined to be infected with rabies after examination by a licensed veterinarian it shall be euthanized at the cost of the owner i it shall be unlawful for any person owning possessing keeping harboring or having custody of any animal that has bitten any other animal or person to sell give away or permit such biting animal to be taken beyond the corporate limits of the city or otherwise dispose of any such biting animal until it is released by the animal warden j in all cases where an animal has bitten a person or another animal it shall be the duty and responsibility of the animal warden or deputy animal warden or in their absence or unavailability the duty and responsibility of the police department to investigate and fill out an animal report bite form using information from the bite victims their families animal owners and any other person having knowledge of an animal bite which forms shall be kept on record by the animal warden k if an animal that has bitten a person dies is accidentally killed or is humanely euthanized before the tenth day following the bite such animal shall have its head removed packed in an ice container and the head forwarded immediately to the state board of health laboratory for examination if such a biting animal is a small animal such as a bat mouse or hamster the body of the entire animal shall be forwarded to the state board of health laboratory for examination l any person violating this section upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 116  state law reference exposure of person to rabies ic 1521611 animals creating a nuisance a it shall be unlawful for any owner to allow his dog or animal to become a public nuisance b a dog or animal is hereby declared to be a public nuisance if it 1 frequently or continuously causes noise or odor which disturbs the comfort or repose of persons in any dwelling apartment house or residence  2 molests or chases passersby or passing vehicles  3 is repeatedly at large  4 attacks other persons or animals  5 damages private or public property  or 6 deposits animal waste on public or private property other than that of the owner a b   11895 animal waste a it shall be unlawful for any owner or any person exerting control of any animal to permit such animal to defecate or leave its waste on any public or private property other than the private property of its owner b any person who permits any animal to defecate or leave its waste upon an unauthorized place shall be required to immediately remove such excrement  proclamation of quarantine a whenever it becomes necessary to safeguard the public from dangers of rabies the mayor if he deems it necessary to prevent the spread thereof shall issue a proclamation ordering every person owning or keeping a dog cat or other animal capable of carrying rabies to confine it securely on his premises unless such dog or other animal shall have a muzzle of sufficient strength to prevent it from biting any person or other animal and on a leash under the control of the owner or responsible person b any unmuzzled dog cat or other such animal not on a leash found during the time of the proclamation shall be seized and impounded c any dog cat or other such animal found at large during the time of the proclamation which has been impounded and found to be infected with rabies shall be euthanized d any dog cat or other such animal found at large during the time of such proclamation and found not to be infected with footnotes  2  editors note  adopted dec 6 201 repealed the former div 3  105610597 and enacted a new div 3 as set out herein the former div 3 pertained to dangerous dog regulations and protection and derived from  adopted    adopted sept 6 2011 determination of a dangerous animal a any person may submit a report of a dangerous animal to the animal warden b upon receipt of a valid report of a dangerous animal the animal warden shall investigate the facts and circumstances surrounding the allegation that said animal is dangerous and prepare a written report stating whether the animal is dangerous the animal warden may impose reasonable conditions on the owner of the dangerous animal in order to ensure the effective restraint of the dangerous animal as well as public safety the reasonable conditions include but are not limited to the following 1 humane destruction of the dangerous animal  2 confinement of the dangerous animal  andor 3 owners purchase of liability insurance c if the animal warden determines that the animal is dangerous and imposes reasonable conditions on the owner the following shall occur 1 the dangerous animal shall be immediately impounded if not already 2 if the owner of the dangerous animal agrees to the proposed conditions the owner shall have three days to pay for all impoundment kennel and penalty fees incurred to date and to post a bond equal to 15 days impoundment and kennel fees the owner shall have 15 days from the date of notice of the proposed conditions to provide sufficient evidence of compliance with the conditions the dangerous animal shall remain impounded until such evidence of compliance is provided 3 if the owner of the dangerous animal disagrees with the proposed conditions the dangerous animal shall remain impounded and the owner shall have the right to appeal the decision to the porter county indiana superior or circuit court the owner shall have three days to pay for all impoundment kennel and penalty fees incurred to date and to post a bond equal to 30 days impoundment and kennel fees the owner shall renew the bond at the end of each 30 day period until the court issues an order in the appeal if the owner fails to pay for all impoundment kennel and penalty fees incurred and to post a bond equal to 30 days impoundment and kennel fees within three days of notice of the proposed conditions or fails to renew the bond at the end of a 30 day period then the owner shall be presumed to have surrendered all rights and claim of ownership and control of the animal d if the animal warden determines that an animal is not a dangerous animal then the animal shall be released to its owner after compliance with all impoundment and release procedures and fees  12616 acquisition of a dangerous dog this article animal any live nonhuman vertebrate or invertebrate creature that is domestic wild or exotic animal control agency any governmental or private entity charged with or contracted with and given authority for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter for and on behalf of the city animal warden a person authorized to carry out the provisions of this chapter when used in this chapter animal warden shall be read to include the deputy animal warden and any law enforcement officer designated by the animal warden exotic animal any animal whose normal native habitat is not indigenous to the continental united states excluding alaska and hawaii this definition does not include fish furbearing animals commercially bred for the furrier trade and birds protected under federal laws and regulations owner any person having temporary or permanent custody of sheltering or having charge of harboring exercising control over or having property rights to any animal covered by this chapter pet any animal kept for pleasure rather than utility pet shop any person group of persons partnership or corporation whether operated separately or in connection with another business enterprise which sells or barters animals  5306 general animal care requirements every pet shop operating within the corporate limits of the city shall see that each of its animals a is kept in a clean sanitary and healthy manner and is not confined so as to be forced to stand sit or lie in its own excrement  b has sufficient and wholesome food and water which is proper and nutritional for that species of animal  c lives in a structure meeting minimum veterinary standards which will protect that animal from all elements of the weather and will allow that animal to stand sit and lie down without restriction and which is kept in a sanitary manner  d if ill diseased or injured receives proper and timely veterinary care as necessary to promote the good health of the animal and prevent the transmittal of a disease to other animals or human beings  e is not beaten illtreated overloaded tormented or otherwise abused or neglected or involved in any dog fight cockfight bullfight or other combat between animals and humans  f is not physically altered in any manner by anyone other than a veterinarian except for tattooing for identification purposes and grooming specifically no rabbit chick gosling duckling turkey or other fowl may be dyed or otherwise colored artificially  nor shall any dyed or artificially colored rabbits chicks goslings ducklings turkeys or other fowl be sold offered for sale displayed used as barter or given away g is not abandoned neglected or tortured  h in the case of a dog or cat over the age of three months is properly vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian annually or upon such frequency as may be specified by state law and such animals shall be licensed as required by this chapter and state law  i is properly restrained and not at large  j during mating season is kept in a secure enclosure in such a manner that it cannot come into contact with another animal of the same species except for planned breeding  k is not transported in an unenclosed truck bed or open section of any vehicle unless the animal is enclosed in a cage which is securely fastened to the vehicle at the request of an animal warden a law enforcement officer may act to remedy the hazard by any means including gaining entry to impound the endangered animal  5306 dangerous and poisonous animals no pet shop shall harbor possess sell offer for sale buy or attempt to buy within the city any poisonous animal whether by birth or otherwise reptile amphibian fish or insect or any animal that poses a threat to the public health and safety such animal may be impounded by the animal control agency and disposed of in a manner determined to be in the best interest of the animal and the public  5306 protected animals a no pet shop shall possess offer for sale sell attempt to buy or buy within the city any of the following animals of either thoroughbred or hybrid stock or pedigree 1 all wild cats of the family felidae  2 wolves  3 vicuna vicugna  4 alligator  5 caiman or crocodile  6 sea otter enhydra lutris  7 pacific ridley turtle lepidochelys olivacea  8 atlantic green turtle chelonia mydas  9 mexican ridley turtle lepidochelys kempi  10 any animal poisonous by birth or otherwise including rearfang snakes  11 constrictor snakes including but not limited to boa python and anaconda  12 game cocks and other fighting birds  13 monkeys including old world cercopithecidae and new world  14 piranha fish characidae  15 spiders and insects which are poisonous  16 monitor lizard  or 17 wild animals including but not limited to raccoons skunks foxes squirrels and chipmunks b no pet shop shall buy sell or offer for sale or own a native or foreign species or subspecies of mammal bird amphibian fish or reptile or the dead body or parts thereof which appears on the threatened and endangered species list designated by the united states secretary of the interior and published in the federal regulations pursuant to the endangered species act of 1969 public law 135 91st congress as amended c no pet shop shall import or cause to be imported into the city any part of the plumage skin or dead body of any species of hawk owl or eagle d an animal warden may seize and impound any animal being offered for sale or owned in violation of this section in addition to any fines issued for violation of this section the person or firm violating any provision of this section shall be responsible for any and all costs expended by the animal control agency in transporting keeping andor handling the animals  5306 pet shop permit a no person partnership or corporation shall operate a pet shop without first obtaining from the city a pet shop permit and paying the necessary fees any person holding a pet shop under state law  6 vaccination and parasite medication administered to the animal date administered and name of veterinarian or person who administered the same  and 7 guarantee of good health for a period of not less than one week with recommendation to have the animal examined by a licensed veterinarian b the permit holder shall retain a copy of the written statement for a period of 12 months from the date of sale and provide a duplicate copy to the licensing authority if the purchaser resides within the corporate limits of the city c the permit holder shall also deliver to the purchaser at the time of sale a written statement of the registration and licensing requirements applicable to the purchased animal if the purchaser resides within the corporate limits of the city such statement shall be prepared by the city and provided by the animal control agency d all pet shops shall take care to house animals in a sanitary manner and to provide appropriate veterinary services hearing before the board of public works and safety of the city a pet shops permit however shall only be revoked after the board finds that the pet shop owner or permit holder has failed to comply
