or keep any nuisance thereon nor shall any person keep or maintain such premises in a manner causing substantial diminution in the value of the other property in the neighborhood in which such premises are located all property located within the city shall be maintained within the following minimum standards property a all fences and walls shall be maintained in a structurally sound manner to protect the public safety b all grass and weeds and other vegetation shall be maintained so that the height shall not exceed six inches this provision excludes trees shrubs ornamental grasses wildflowers and other cultivated plants c all premises shall be free from any stagnant water d all outbuildings and accessory structures shall be maintained in a structurally sound manner to protect the public safety e all property including but not limited to undedicated streets alleys and throughways shall be maintained in a manner so that it does not create or constitute a public nuisance f all property included but not limited to undedicated streets alleys and throughways shall be maintained in a sound manner to protect the public safety g all private property shall be kept free from graffiti at the owners expense h branches extending over pedestrian walkways shall be maintained so that their height shall not be lower than seven feet i trees and shrubs which extend over any public road or street shall be maintained so that there is clearance of at least 15 feet over the road or street open and outdoor storage the open and outdoor storage of appliances building materials or rubbish equipment garbage goods glass material merchandise rubbish trash or similar items shall not be permitted maintained or stored on any premises exceptions a this section shall not prohibit the storage of debris in leakproof containers with closefitting covers to prevent the distribution of debris by the elements until removed from the premises for proper disposal b cut firewood for the personal use of the owner or occupant which is neatly and safely stacked in lengths not to exceed three feet the cut firewood is to be stacked in the rear of the property c likewise it shall not prevent outdoor storage where permitted by municipal code these exemptions shall not be interpreted to permit activity that would otherwise be prohibited by zoning laws composting all compost piles shall be maintained using approved composting procedures to comply with the following requirements a all compost piles shall be enclosed in a controlled standing compost system each pile shall be no taller than three feet and no wider than five feet b the compost system shall provide adequate penetration of moisture for the compost materials and provide adequate ventilation for products or decomposition c all compost piles shall be maintained as to prevent the attraction of rodents and pests d all compost piles shall be maintained to prevent unpleasant odors e the compost pile shall be located within the rear of the property unless the residence is located in the back of the property in those instances the property owner shall contact the department of planning regarding placement of the compost pile  12704   8508  b 9908   6309   8310   10615   8718 exterior structures 1 all exterior surfaces including but not limited to doors door and window frames cornices porches and trim siding and masonry joints shall be maintained weather resistant and watertight 2 all porches decks balconies exterior stairways and all appurtenances attached thereto shall be maintained in a structurally sound manner capable of supporting the imposed load and free from any hazardous conditions 3 exterior walls of buildings shall be maintained free from holes breaks loose or rotting substantially prevent rain and wind from entering a building additionally exterior doors shall be provided with proper hardware and maintained in proper working condition swimming pools and spas all swimming pools hot tubs spas or any other waterfilled area shall be maintained in a sanitary condition to avoid the creation of any health hazard or a breeding ground for diseasecarrying insects development f a reasonable estimate of revenues that 1 are from sources other than impact fees  and 2 will be used to finance the cost identified in subsection e1 above  g a description of the nature and location of existing infrastructure in the impact zone h a general description of the sources and amounts of money used to pay for infrastructure during the previously five years additionally the review board and the city impact fee review board shall conduct a hearing with regard thereto at such hearing the fee payer shall bear the burden of going forward with the evidence and shall present evidence addressing either of the following propositions a a fact assumption used in determining the amount of the fee is incorrect  or b the amount of the fee is greater than the amount allowed under ic 36741320 36741321 and 36741322 upon conclusion of the hearing at which the matter is first presented or at the conclusion of the hearing if the matter is continued the city impact fee review board shall determine the appropriate amount of the fee based upon the facts presented and may reverse affirm modify or make such adjustments in the fee as it believes are appropriate under the circumstances if any including establishing the amount of an impact fee a credit a refund or any combination of fees credit or refunds the city impact fee review board shall make written findings of fact supporting its decision and shall provide a copy of its decision to the city council and the fee payer involved in the appeal within five days after making its decision an appeal under this section must be filed no later than 30 days after the issuance of the building permit the appeal shall be initiated with the filing of a petition for review with the city clerktreasurers office together with a filing fee in the amount of $10000 the filing fee shall be refunded in full if 1 the petition for review is granted and the fee is eliminated reduced or adjusted by the city impact fee review board by independent action of the city or by a court having jurisdiction  and 2 the reviewing body determines that the amount of the fee reductions or credits were arbitrary or capricious the petition for review shall be in a form calculated to inform the city impact fee review board of the nature of complaint the parties to the action and the relief requested in addition the petition shall describe the new development on which the fee has been assessed all facts related to the assessment of the fee and the reasons the petitioner believes that the amount of the fee assessed is erroneous or is greater than the amount allowed by the fee limitation set forth in this article and the enabling statute the city shall not deny the issuance of a building permit on the basis that the impact fee has not been paid or condition issuance of the permit on the payment of the impact fee if the impact fee totals $100000 or less the city may require the fee payer to pay the impact fee or initiate an appeal under this section before the building permit is issued  11414 establishment of park and recreation impact fee fund there is hereby established the park and recreation impact fee drug and alcohol program policy statement this article is adopted to prevent the illegal presence of drugs and alcohol in the work place and to comply with the drug free work place act of 1988 i 81092 awareness education an awareness and education program shall be established for all employees of the city which shall 1 provide important timely factual information about the hazards of alcohol and drug abuse in the work place as well as provide in service training to all employees 2 train the supervisory level employees on chemical dependency with specific focus on effective employee communications ii 81092 employee assistance an employee assistance program shall be established and made available to all employees of the city the primary goal of the employee assistance program is to provide an effective confidential nonthreatening environment in which an employee of the city can seek help without the fear of career damage iii 81092 drug testing to reduce the incidence and prevalence of alcohol and drug abuse in the work place and to promote and foster confidence in the services provided by the city a system of identifying as early as possible an employee who is abusing drugs shall be established the drug testing policy shall comply with the following guidelines 1 preemployment all applicants for a vacant position within the city will be required to be tested for the presence of illegal or abused substances notwithstanding the foregoing applicants for seasonal positions as referees and umpires at the park department shall not be subject to preemployment drug testing 2 postemployment any employee may be required to submit to a test to determine the presence of illegal or abused substances when there is reasonable suspicion reasonable suspicion shall be defined as the presence or occurrence of specific objective facts or events that the employee is at the time of suspicion under the influence of drugs andor alcohol such facts or events must be documented in writing and may include but are not limited to the following a observed possession or use of drugs or alcohol by the employee on the job or prior to reporting offduty b the smell of marijuana or alcohol on the employees person c the occurrence of an accident or incident involving personal injury or damage to property d mood swings agitation hyperactivity explosiveness violence combativeness or other remarkable behavior that is uncharacteristic of the employee e excessive absenteeism tardiness or other significant documented changes in employee performance 3 employees affecting public health and safety any employee who may directly impact on the public safety ie police officers firemen street department employees may be required to submit to a test for the presence of illegal or abused substances on a periodic basis at time intervals to be determined by the board of public works and safety iv 81092   6600   4301 discipline for violation of drugfree policy any employee determined to be under the influence of illegal drugs andor alcohol is subject to discipline including termination any employee who is convicted of a criminal drug statute in the work place must inform the city within five days of such a conviction when the city learns of the conviction the city must appropriately discipline the employee the police merit commission the fire merit commission and the board of public works and safety are each authorized to implement and impose any applicable discipline to the employees of the city under their respective jurisdictions v 81092 implementation the board of public works and safety shall adopt policies and procedures for the implementation of the awareness education employee assistance and drug testing programs in accordance with the terms of this article vi 81092 secs 6211262119  reserved article v  collective bargaining policy statement public policy it shall be the public policy of the city of portage to allow collective bargaining in what the city deems to be appropriate bargaining units after an election in which a simple majority of employees in the bargaining unit establish that they wish to be represented by a labor organization elected officials professional employees confidential employees and managers and supervisors are excepted from this article the city recognizes that employees may form join or assist labor organizations and to bargain collectively of their own choosing the city further recognizes however that employees also have the right to refrain from any and all such activities and shall have the right to represent themselves individually in their employment relations with the city nothing contained herein shall be deemed to supersede the provisions of existing state law  definitions appropriate bargaining unit means a group of employees designated by the board of public works and safety board for the purpose of collective bargaining confidential employee means a person who assists and acts in a confidential capacity with respect to a management employee employee means a regular fulltime nonprobationary employee of the city of portage employer means the city of portage labor organization means any employee organization which seeks andor successfully establishes that it has majority support among an appropriate bargaining unit lockout means an act by the employer to prevent its employees from going to work for the purpose of resisting a demand of the employees exclusive representative or for the purpose of gaining a concession from the exclusive representative professional employee means an employee whose work is predominately intellectual and varied in character and whose work involves the consistent exercise of discretion and judgment in its performance and require knowledge of an advanced nature in a field of learning customarily requiring specialized study at an institution of higher education or its equivalent the work of a professional employee is of such character that the output or result accomplished cannot be standardized in relation to a given period of time strike means an employees refusal in concerted action with other employees to report for duty or his willful absence in whole or in part from the full faithful and proper performance of the duties of employment the definition of strike includes but is not limited to such action as the blue flu sickouts slowdowns and sympathy strikes supervisor means any individual having authority in the interest of the employer to hire transfer suspend discipline other employees or responsibility to direct them or responsibility for evaluating employees work performance or to adjust their grievances or effectively to recommend any of the actions listed above if in connection with the foregoing the exercise of such authority is not of a merely routine or clerical nature but requires the use of independent judgment  11601 appropriate bargaining units the board shall upon receipt of a valid petition for a representation election filed by a labor organization designate the appropriate bargaining unit for collective bargaining  11601 determination of representation a any labor organization may file a written request with the board asserting that employees in a bargaining unit of the city desire to be represented by it for the purpose of collective bargaining and asking to be recognized as the exclusive bargaining representative the request shall include a demonstration of support of at least 30 percent of the employees in the bargaining unit by means of a dated membership list or signed and dated membership cards of those employees desiring representation notice of the request shall be posted by the city in a place conspicuous to employees in the bargaining unit b upon authentication of the list or cards the board shall call and hold a representation election within 45 days from the date that the board determines the appropriateness of the bargaining unit such election shall not be held if 1 there is currently in effect a lawful written agreement between the city and an exclusive bargaining representative for the bargaining unit  2 within the preceding 12 months there has been held a representation election or a decertification election for the bargaining unit  or 3 voluntary recognition has been granted in the past 12 months c the board shall call and hold all elections within the time limits established by this section and according to the following 1 included on the ballot in a representation election shall be any employee organizations submitting evidence of support of at least 30 percent of the city employees in the bargaining unit and a choice for no representation the choices on a ballot in a decertification election shall be the incumbent exclusive bargaining representative no representation and any employee organizations submitting evidence of support of at least 30 percent of the city employees in the bargaining unit  2 voting shall be by secret ballot  3 where a simple majority of the votes cast are in favor of representation by a labor organization and at least 60 percent of the employees in the bargaining unit have cast a vote the board shall certify the labor organization as the exclusive representation for all employees in that appropriate bargaining unit no labor organization shall be certified as an exclusive representative unless at least 60 percent of the employees in the bargaining unit vote in the election or runoff election this subsection does not apply to decertification elections in a decertification election the labor organization must receive a simple majority of the votes cast in order to retain certification as representative of the employees in a bargaining unit d notwithstanding the provisions of subsections ac of this section the employer is required to recognize as the exclusive representative of its employees within an appropriate unit a labor organization which presents to the employer evidence of its representation of a simple majority of the employees within the unit unless any other organization employee group of employees or labor organization representing employees within the unit files written objections to recognition with the board in the absence of such objections the board is not required to hold a hearing or to direct an election before recognizing an exclusive representative under the circumstances of this subsection the board is required to post a written public notice of its intention to recognize the organization as exclusive representative of the employees within the unit the notice must be posted for at least 30 days immediately preceding recognition in the event objections are filed an election shall be conducted in accordance with this section e the certified exclusive bargaining representative shall represent all employees covered by the terms of the collective bargaining agreement whether or not the employees choose to join the union f the decertification of any employee organization which has been recognized as the exclusive bargaining representative of employees in an appropriate bargaining unit may be effected by the filing of a written request for decertification supported by a showing that 30 percent of the employees in the bargaining unit seek to have a decertification election if in the opinion of the board the showing of interest in support of such a petition is sufficient within 45 days a decertification election shall be held g no decertification election shall be held if within the preceding 12 months the board has held a representation election or decertification election for the bargaining unit h the following meetings shall be closed as defined by the open door law 1 meetings for discussion of bargaining strategy for collective bargaining negotiations between the employer and the exclusive representative  and 2 collective bargaining sessions i a labor organization certified as the exclusive bargaining representative for employees prior to the effective date of this article shall be recognized without following the certification procedures set forth in this article if such a labor organization is decertified the provisions of the article shall apply to its recertification  11601 prohibited practices no organization its representative or other individual shall be allowed to solicit membership for an employee organization or labor union during an employees duty hours by calling or holding a group meeting unless authorized by agreement  11601 strikes and lockouts prohibited  penalties and sanctions a no employee or labor organization shall engage in a strike no labor organization shall cause instigate encourage or support a strike walkout or slowdown the employer shall not cause instigate or engage in any employee lockout b in the case of an action by bargaining unit employees where the employer alleges a strike has occurred the board shall meet in emergency session within 24 hours of the disclosure of this information and determine whether a strike has indeed occurred c the board after determining that a strike has occurred shall direct that the collective bargaining agreement ceases to exist and shall declare that the exclusive representative no longer represents employees in the bargaining unit involved the board shall notify the employees in the subject bargaining unit of such action and advise them that they will not be privileged to bargain with the city collective bargaining agent for at least 12 months in such case the exclusive representative that represented the employees who went on strike shall be prohibited from collecting dues deductions negotiating or representing employees in any fashion and shall be barred from serving as the exclusive representative of any bargaining unit of employees for a minimum of 12 months at which time the city shall negotiate a new agreement unless decertification has occurred d in the case of a violation of this section the city may petition the appropriate court to 1 issue an order restraining and enjoining such violation  2 in the case of a strike walkout or slowdown impose on the employee organization a fine which will be set in accordance with the damages loss of revenue andor services involved  11601 agreements upon certification of an exclusive bargaining representative the city and its representatives and the union andor its representatives shall meet and confer at reasonable times and places to attempt to negotiate a collective bargaining agreement the citys bargaining representatives shall include at least two but no more than three members of the common council appointed by the common council president at least one common council member shall be present at all bargaining meetings a nothing in this article shall prevent the employer from negotiating on any issues unless prevented by state or federal law b all agreements reached between the city and an exclusive bargaining representative as a result of collective bargaining will be reduced to writing in the form of a contract between the parties c a handexecuted copy of the agreement will be provided to each party and each will bear the cost of reproducing copies as needed the city is responsible for providing copies and orientation to management employees supervisors and confidential employees the exclusive representative is responsible for providing copies and orientation to the employees in the bargaining unit d an agreement is effective when the union president and the mayor sign the agreement and it is approved by the common council provisions in multiyear agreements providing for economic increases in subsequent years shall be contingent upon the common council appropriating sufficient funds to fund the agreedupon increase for a subsequent year  11601   6512 payroll deduction of employee organization fees the employer may upon receipt of a written and dated authorization of an employee deduct from the pay of such employee any fees designated or certified by the appropriate officer of that employees exclusive bargaining representative and shall remit those fees to the employees organization provided that such authorization was executed subsequent to the passage of this article and presented to the employer within ten days of its execution provided further that such deductions are authorized by a valid collective bargaining agreement employees may be required pursuant to the terms of a lawful fair share agreement to pay a fee which shall be their proportionate share of the costs of the collective bargaining process contract administration and pursuing matters affecting wages hours and other conditions of employment  11601 unfair labor practices a it shall be an unfair labor practice for an employer to 1 interfere with restrain or coerce employees in the exercise of their right to join a labor organization  2 discriminate in regard to hiring or condition of employment to encourage or discourage membership in any labor organization  3 refuse to bargain collectively with an exclusive representative b it shall be an unfair labor practice for a labor organization or its agents to 1 restrain or coerce employees in the exercise of their rights  2 refuse to bargain collectively with an employer if the labor organization is the exclusive representative  11601 employment relations committee in the event a complaint is filed alleging that any person has engaged in or is engaging in an unfair labor practice as provided in this article the mayor at his discretion may appoint a special committee to investigate it in an attempt to resolve the complaint a only persons who have a minimum of three years of experience directly related to labor and employment relations in representing public employers private employers or labor organizations  or teaching labor or employment relations  or administering executive orders or regulations applicable to labor or employment relations shall be appointed to the committee b however the mayor andor the city council may change these requirements if the mayor is unable to find suitable appointees meeting these qualifications c members of the committee shall hold no other public office or employment by the city state or other public agency or public employer or be an officer or employee of any employee organization or any of its affiliates who represent or seek to represent employees employed by the city however this restriction does not apply to persons on the teaching staff of a university who are knowledgeable in public administration or labor law so long as they are not actively engaged other than as a member with any labor or employee organization  11601 impasse either the employer or an exclusive representative may declare that an impasse has been reached between them in collective bargaining over the terms and conditions of employment and may request to participate in nonbinding mediation with federal mediation and conciliatory services the services of the mediator including applicable per diem expenses shall be borne equally by the parties any individually incurred costs shall be borne by the party incurring them nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the parties from mutually agreeing to substitute an alternate procedure for resolving impasses in collective bargaining with that provided herein or from agreeing to utilize the services of a mediator not affiliated with federal mediation and conciliatory services  11601 planning and development footnotes  1  editors note of adopted  repealed ch 66 in its entirety former ch article ii  definitions and interpretations division 1  definitions and rules of word usage word usage the following rules of word usage apply to the text of this chapter 1 the particular shall control the general 2 in case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text of this chapter and any caption illustration summary table or illustrative table the text shall control 3 the word shall is always mandatory and not discretionary the word may is permissive 4 words used in the present tense shall include the future  words used in the singular number shall include the plural and the plural the singular unless the context clearly indicates the contrary  use of gender specific pronouns shall be interpreted to include both sexes 5 a building or structure includes any part thereof 6 the phrase used for includes arranged for designed for intended for maintained for or occupied by 7 unless the context clearly indicates the contrary where a regulation involves two or more items conditions provisions or events connected by the conjunction and or or eitheror the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows a and indicates that all the connected items conditions provisions or events shall apply b or indicates that the connected items conditions provision or events may apply singly or in any combination c eitheror indicates that the connected items conditions provision or events shall apply singly but not in combination 8 the word includes shall not limit a term to the specified examples but is intended to extend its meaning to all other instances or circumstances of like kind or character 9 the title planning director as used in this chapter shall include planning staff as designated by the director art 2 div 1  1 7699 terms defined wherever in this chapter any of the following terms are used they shall have the meaning indicated hereafter in this article block means the property abutting one side of a street and lying between the two nearest intersecting or intercepting streets or between the nearest intersecting or intercepting street and railroad rightofway unsubdivided acreage lake river or live stream  or between any of the foregoing and any other barrier to the continuity of development or corporate boundary lines of the city building line means a line formed by the face of the building and for the purposes of this chapter a minimum building line is the same as a front building setback line building setback line front means a line establishing the minimum allowable distance between a street or other rightofway and any structure as measured from the front property line or rightofway see yard required building setback line side or rear means a line establishing the minimum allowable distance between a property line and any structure as measured from the property line see yard required city means the city of portage indiana city engineer means a qualified civil engineer registered in the state of indiana employed by the city in the capacity of city engineer comprehensive plan includes the complete comprehensiveland use plan of the city of portage and its planning jurisdiction and all of its subsequent amendments for the development of the city prepared by the plan commission and legally adopted construction means onsite erection fabrication installation alteration demolition or removal of any structure facility or addition thereto including all related activities including but not restricted to excavation clearing of land blasting and landscaping culdesac means a short street having one open end to traffic and being permanently terminated by a vehicle turnaround developer means any person engaged in subdivision of or construction on a lot or group of lots or structures thereon easement means land or an interest in land that has been designated by lawful agreement between the owner or owners of the land and another person or persons for a specified use only by such person or persons fhbm means the flood hazard boundary map final plat means a map of subdivision with accompanying material intended for final approval and recording on the basis of which land can be transferred leased or encumbered firm means the flood insurance rate map flood means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow the unusual and rapid accumulation or the runoff of surface waters from any source flood regulatory means the flood having a one percent probability of being equaled or exceeded in any given year as calculated by a method and procedure which is acceptable to and approved by the state natural resources commission the regulatory flood elevation at any location is as defined in article iv division 4 section 66203 the regulatory flood is also known by the term base flood flood protection grade or fpg means the elevation of the regulatory flood plus two feet at any given location in the sfha floodplain means the channel proper and the areas adjoining any wetland lake or watercourse which have been or hereafter may be covered by the regulatory flood the floodplain includes both the floodway and the floodway fringe districts floodway means the channel of a river or stream and those portions of the floodplains adjoining the channel which are reasonably required to efficiently carry and discharge the peak flood flow of the regulatory flood of any river or stream floodway fringe includes those portions of the floodplain lying outside the floodway front yard setback means in all cases the front yard setback shall be measured from the rightofway as shown on the adopted thoroughfare plan grade means the ground elevation established for the purpose of regulating the number of stories and the height of buildings or structures the established grade shall be either 1 the finished grade if the finished grade is level or 2 the average grade if the finished grade is not level grade average means the average of the elevation of the ground for each face of the building or structure grade finished means the level of the ground adjacent to a building or structure jurisdiction means the incorporated territory of the city lowest floor means the lowest of the following 1 the basement floor  2 the garage floor if the garage is the lowest level of the building  3 the first floor of buildings elevated on pilings or constructed on a crawl space with permanent openings  or 4 the floor level of any enclosure below an elevated building where the walls of the enclosure provide any resistance to the flow of floodwaters unless a the walls are designed to automatically equalize the hydrostatic flood forces on the walls by allowing for the entry and exit of flood waters a minimum of two openings in addition to doorways and windows having a total area of one square foot for every two square feet of enclosed floor area subject to flooding the bottom of all such openings shall be no higher than one foot above the enclosed areas floor b such enclosed space shall be usable for nonresidential purposes and building access a document containing regulations written either to stand on their own or as an amendment to an existing ordinance which when adopted by the common council becomes legally binding parcel map means a map or drawing generally depicting subdivision data plan commission means the city plan commission planning director means the officer in charge of planning department who is appointed to administer the unified development code planning jurisdiction see jurisdiction plat means a map or chart indicating the subdivision or resubdivision of land intended to be filed for record public utility means a person municipal department board or commission duly authorized to furnish and furnishing under federal state or municipal regulation to the public gas steam electricity sewage disposal communication telegraph transportation or water rightofway means a parcel of land or easement either public or private on which an irrevocable rightofaccess has been recorded for vehicles or pedestrians or both a public rightofway is one which has been dedicated for public use and may include streets alleys or sidewalks roadway means the portion of a street rightofway available for vehicular movement roadway width shall be measured from back of curb to back of curb setback means the distance required to obtain minimum front side or rear yard open space provisions of this chapter see building setback front building setback side and rear and tower setback special flood hazard area sfha includes those lands within the jurisdiction of the city that are subject to inundation by the regulatory flood the sfhas of the city are generally identified as such on the flood insurance rate map and corresponding flood boundary floodway map of the city prepared by the federal emergency management agency and dated  the sfhas of those parts of the unincorporated county that are within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city or that may be annexed into the city are generally identified as such on the flood insurance rate map and corresponding flood boundary floodway map prepared for the county by the federal emergency management agency and dated  street means a rightofway other than an alley usually affording the principal means of access to abutting property the street may be designated as a highway thoroughfare parkway boulevard road avenue lane drive or other appropriate name street access means local streets which are parallel to and adjacent to arterial streets and highways street arterial primary means a public street of large rightofway so designated in the thoroughfare plan and intended primarily for moving large volumes of traffic between origin and destination within a region street arterial secondary means a public street of moderate rightofway so designated in the thoroughfare plan and intended primarily for moving moderate volumes of traffic between origin and destination within a region street collector means a public street of smaller rightofway so designated in the thoroughfare plan and intended to collect traffic generated by local streets and carry it to arterials street feeder as regards entrance and exit ramps means a street usually an arterial which provides access to and from an expressway by virtue of exit and entrance ramps to which it is connected street local means a public street intended for access to abutting properties street private means a paved area other than a driveway located on private property for the purpose of providing vehicular or pedestrian access to and within that property see also drive and driveway street public means a public way for purposes of vehicular or pedestrian travel including the entire area within the rightofway subdivider means any person engaged in developing or improving a tract of land which complies with the definition of subdivision subdivision means the division of any parcel of land shown as a unit as part of a unit or as continuous units on the last preceding transfer of ownership thereof into two or more parcels sites or lots any of which is less than five acres in area for the purpose whether immediate or future of transfer of ownership  provided however that the division or partition of land into parcels of more than five acres not involving any new streets or easements of access and the sale or exchange of parcels between adjoining lot owners where such sale or exchange does not create additional building sites shall not be considered a subdivision subdivision shall also mean the improvement of one or more parcels of land for residential commercial or industrial structures or groups of structures involving the subdivision and allocation of land as streets or other open spaces for common use by owners occupants or lease holders or as easements for the extension and maintenance of public sewer water storm drainage or other public utilities and facilities thoroughfare means a public rightofway intended for the effective movement of pedestrian and vehicular traffic thoroughfare plan means the part of the comprehensive plan which sets forth the location classification general design and construction priorities of existing and proposed public streets to ensure effective vehicular movement effective use of the land and economic use of the public funds variance means a modification of the literal provisions of the ordinance granted when strict enforcement of the ordinance would cause undue hardship owing to the circumstances unique to the individual property on which the variance is granted the crucial points of variance are 1 undue hardship  2 unique circumstances  and 3 applying to property a variance is not justified unless all three elements are present in the case a variance is not an exception wetland means an area that is inundated or saturated by surface water or ground water at a frequency and duration sufficient to support and that under normal circumstances does support a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions commonly known as hydrophytic vegetation art 2 div 1  2 7699   8205 secs 66636670  reserved division 2  reserved footnotes  4  editors note  adopted aug 2 200 art iii which pertained to administrative bodies and derived from art 3 div 1  1  and art 3 div 2  14 adopted  secs 669166150  reserved article iv  administrative procedures division 1  subdivision procedure purpose the purpose of the subdivision requirements of this development code is to promote the public health safety general welfare and preserve the aesthetic quality of the city regulation and control of the division of land to achieve this purpose the regulations contained in this development code are determined to be necessary to promote orderly growth and development open space conservation protection and proper use of land  and to ensure adequate provision for traffic circulation utilities and other services in the city art 4 div 1  1 7699 subdivision approval process an applicant desiring approval of a primary or secondary plat of a subdivision of any land lying within the jurisdiction of the plan commission shall comply with the following procedure 1 every applicant shall participate in a preapplication meeting with the city of portage planning department the purpose of the meeting is to a acquaint the developer with the citys standards and requirements of all ordinances and the comprehensive plan b review the intent of the procedures and requirements of the city c acquaint the developer with any limiting characteristics of the property under review 2 upon receipt of a completed application the applicant will be placed on a drc agenda the applicant and hisher agent shall attend the meeting 3 applications for primary and secondary plats shall be reviewed and forwarded to the plan commission within 30 days of receipt of a completed application drc recommendations based upon the goals and objectives of the city of portage comprehensive plan as well as the established zoning and development standards of the city of portage will accompany the completed application 4 a primary plat shall be reviewed and voted upon by the plan commission in a public hearing as set forth in this division 5 a secondary plat shall be reviewed and voted upon by the plan commission signed by the president and executive secretary of the plan commission and filed with the porter county recorder as set forth in this division art 4 div 1  2 7699   8602 general restrictions a the following actions may occur once the final plat has been signed and recorded 1 the granting of an improvement location permit or the construction of any public improvements authorized thereby  2 contracts made for the sale of any part of the subdivision b no building permit shall be issued until the plat has been recorded c no building permit shall be issued for the construction of any building or structure located on a lot or plat subdivided or sold in violation of the provisions of this article iv administrative procedures art 4 div 1  3 7699 resubdivisions replats a for any change in a map of an approved or recorded subdivision plat if such change affects any street layout shown on such map or area reserved thereon for public use or any lot line or if it affects any map or plan legally recorded prior to the adoption of any regulations controlling subdivision such change shall be approved by the plan commission by the same procedure rules and regulations as for a subdivision b whenever a parcel of land is subdivided and the subdivision plat shows one or more lots containing more than one acre of land and there are indications that such lots will eventually be resubdivided the plan commission may require that such parcel of land allow for the future opening of streets and the ultimate extension of adjacent streets as a requirement of the plat dedications of rightsofway shall be provided for the future opening and extension of such streets art 4 div 1  4 7699 variances to subdivision standards a variances to subdivision standards of this unified development chapter shall not be granted by the board of zoning appeals but may be granted by the plan commission subject to the applicable requirements herein it is not within the jurisdiction of the board of zoning appeals to grant variances to subdivision regulations b it is the intention of this ordinance that all newly created lots conform to the provisions of this ordinance for lot area and width variances to these or other zoning standards may be granted subject to the provisions of article iv division 5 zoning variances it is not within the jurisdiction of the plan commission to grant variances to zoning regulations c where the plan commission finds that extraordinary hardships or practical difficulties may result from strict compliance with the subdivision regulations of article 4 division 1 or if the purposes of these regulations may be better served by an alternative proposal it may approve variances to said regulations so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured provided that such variances shall not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of these regulations  and further provided the plan commission shall not approve variances unless it shall make findings based upon the evidence presented to it in each specific case that 1 the granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public safety health or welfare or injurious to other property 2 the conditions upon which the request for a variance is based are unique to the property for which the variance is sought and are not applicable generally to other property 3 because of the particular physical surroundings shape or topographical conditions of the specific property involved a particular hardship to the owner would result as distinguished from a mere inconvenience if the strict letter of these regulations are carried out financial hardship does not constitute grounds for a variance 4 the variance will not in any manner vary the provisions of the comprehensive master plan or this unified development chapter 5 where the variance impacts on design and construction of public facilities all appropriate public agencies will be given ample time to comment in writing to the commission d in approving variances the plan commission may require such conditions as will in its judgment secure substantially the objectives of the standards or requirements of these regulations e a petition for any such variance shall be submitted in writing by the subdivider at the time when the sketch plat is filed for the consideration of the planning director the petition shall state fully the grounds for the application and all of the facts relied upon by the petitioner art 4 div 1  5 7699 primary plat contents a the owner or applicant shall provide a primary plat of the subdivision which shall show the manner in based upon adequate test borings and shall be submitted to the planning department b if the city has knowledge of or the preliminary soils report indicates the presence of critically expansive soils liquefaction or other soil problems which if not corrected would lead to structural defects a soils investigation of each lot in the subdivision may be required by the department the soils the recommended action will prevent structural damage to each structure to be constructed and a condition to the issuance of any building permit shall require that the approved recommended action will be incorporated into the construction of each structure 3 title report a preliminary title report acceptable to the department showing the legal owners at the time of filing the tentative map dated procedures of the city engineer 6 phasing if the subdivider plans to file multiple final maps on the tentative map a written notice to this effect shall be filed with the department phase lines shall be shown on the maps 7 solar access any plans and information relating to solar access may be required to be submitted at the time of the tentative map submittal pursuant to the provisions of this development code 8 other reports any other data or reports deemed necessary by the planning director or city engineer art 4 div 1  7 7699 primary plat approval a filing of application after an be deemed an expression of approval to the layout submitted on the primary plat as a guide to the preparation of the secondary plat which will be submitted for approval of the plan commission and for recording upon fulfillment of the requirements of these regulations and the conditions of the conditional approval if any c standards for approval of primary plats no primary plat of a proposed subdivision shall be approved by the plan commission unless the applicant proves by clear and convincing evidence that 1 definite provision has been made for a water supply system that is sufficient in terms of quantity dependability and quality to provide an appropriate supply of water for the type of subdivision proposed  2 if a public sewage system is proposed adequate provision has been made for such a system and if other methods of sewage disposal are proposed that such systems will comply with federal state and local laws and regulations  3 all areas of the proposed subdivision which may involve soil or topographical conditions presenting hazards or requiring special precautions have been identified by the subdivider and that the proposed uses of these areas are compatible with such conditions  4 the subdivider has the financial ability to complete the proposed subdivision in accordance with all applicable federal state and local laws and regulations  5 the proposed subdivision will not result in the scattered subdivision of land that leaves undeveloped parcels of land lacking urban services between developed parcels  6 the subdivider has taken every effort to mitigate the impact of the proposed subdivision on public health safety and welfare 7 in addition to the aforementioned standard all subdivisions shall meet site design and improvement standards of article v d conformance to preexisting regulations every primary plat shall conform to existing zoning regulations and subdivision regulations applicable at the time that the proposed primary is submitted for the approval of the plan commission unless the plan commission has taken official action toward amending the applicable zoning and subdivision regulations and the applicant has reason to know of that action e primary plat approval shall be effective for two years from date of approval by the plan commission the approval shall become null and void unless the subdivider has taken the following steps 1 received secondary plat approval for units as proposed in the primary plat  or 2 renewed the primary plat approval f renewal of plat a primary plat shall be considered for a renewal by the plan commission upon request of the subdivider prior to the expiration date the subdivider shall file a request with the plan commission for renewal of the primary plat approval the plan commission shall review the plat for compliance with current standards and consider the performance of the subdivider to date the plan commission shall consider economic trends and other items which may be affecting the viability of the subdivision to be included but not limited are changes in adjacent land uses extensions or vacations of streets revisions to zoning of abutting land and other items that may be pertinent renewals shall be for a time period of two years art 4 div 1  8 7699   1201 secondary plat a application procedure and requirements 1 the secondary plat may include all or units of local government which have separate governing bodies for the purpose of regulation and control of land use and development as well as for tax purposes art 5 div 1  3 7699 character of land areas shall not be subdivided or developed unless adequate methods are formulated by the developer and approved by the plan commission upon recommendation of the city engineer to solve the problems regulations as established in article i of this chapter art 5 div 2  1 7699 streets and access a the street and alley layout shall provide access to all lots and parcels of land within the subdivision and where streets cross other streets jogs shall not be created b proposed streets shall be adjusted to the contour of the land so as to produce usable lots and streets of reasonable gradient c certain proposed streets where appropriate shall be extended to the boundary line of the tract to be subdivided so as to provide for normal circulation of traffic within the vicinity d wherever there exists a dedicated or platted portion of a street or alley adjacent to the proposed subdivision the remainder of the street or alley to the prescribed width shall be platted within the proposed subdivision e widths of arterial streets and feeder streets shall conform to the width specified in the official thoroughfare plan f the minimum rightofway of residential streets marginal access streets or culdesacs shall be 50 feet all culdesacs shall terminate in a circular rightofway with a minimum diameter of 100 feet or other arrangement for the turning of all vehicles conveniently within the rightofway g alleys shall be discouraged in residential districts but should be included in commercial and industrial areas where needed for loading and unloading for access purposes and where platted shall be at least 20 feet in width h the centerlines of streets should intersect as nearly at right angles as possible i at intersections of alleys and streets property line corners shall be rounded by arcs with at least 25 feet radii or by chords of such arcs j at intersections of streets the property line corners shall be rounded by arcs with radii of not less than 25 feet or by chords of such arcs k if the smaller of the intersection of two streets is less than 60 degrees the radius of the arc at the intersection of property lines shall be increased as deemed advisable by the plan commission l intersections of more than two streets at one point shall be avoided m where parkways or special types of streets are involved the plan commission may apply special standards to be followed in their design n whenever the proposed subdivision contains or is adjacent to a railroad rightofway or a highway designated as a limited access highway by the appropriate highway authorities provision shall be made for a marginal access street or a parallel street at a distance acceptable for the appropriate use of the land between the highway or railroad and such streets o horizontal visibility on curved streets and vertical visibility on all streets must be maintained along the centerlines as follows 1 arterial streets 500 feet  2 feeder streets and parkways 300 feet  and 3 residential streets 150 feet p curvature measured along the centerline shall have a minimum radius as follows 1 arterial streets 500 feet  2 feeder and parkways 300 feet  and 3 residential streets 200 feet q between reversed curves on arterial streets there shall be a tangent of not less than 100 feet and on feeder and residential streets such tangent shall not be less than 40 feet r maximum grades for streets shall be as follows 1 arterial streets not greater than six percent  and 2 feeder and residential streets and alleys not greater than eight percent s the grade of any street gutter line shall not be less than 04 percent art 5 div 2  2 7699 blocks a blocks shall not exceed 1250 feet in length nor be less than 400 feet in length b blocks shall be of sufficient width to permit two tiers of lots of appropriate depth except where an interior street parallels a limited access highway or an arterial street or railroad rightofway c in long blocks the plan commission may require the reservation of an easement block to accommodate utilities drainage facilities or pedestrian traffic pedestrian ways or crosswalks not less than ten feet wide may be required by the plan commission center of blocks more than 600 feet long where deemed essential to provide circulation or access to schools playgrounds shopping centers transportation or other community facilities art 5 div 2  3 7699 a lot arrangement the lot arrangement shall be such that there will be no foreseeable difficulties for reasons of topography or other conditions in securing building permits to build on all lots in compliance with this chapter and health regulations in providing driveway access to buildings on the lots from an approved street or in providing service to public sanitary sewer or approved sanitary disposal facilities all lots shall abut on a street b lot dimension 1 no lot or parcel shall be used for any residential use unless such lot abuts a public street for at least 60 percent of the lot width prescribed for the district in which the lot is located 2 corner residential lots shall be wider than normal in order to permit appropriate setbacks from both streets and the erection of buildings 3 where lots are more than double the minimum required area for the zoning district the plan commission may require that those lots be arranged so as to allow further subdivision and the opening of future streets where they would be necessary to serve potential lots all in compliance with this chapter 4 widths and areas of lots shall be not less than that provided in article vii for the district in which the subdivision is located 5 depth and width of properties reserved or laid out for business commercial or industrial purposes shall be adequate to provide for offstreet parking and loading facilities required for the type of use and development contemplated as established in this chapter c lot lines 1 side lines of lots shall be of approximately right angles to straight streets and on radial lines on curved streets some variation from this rule is permissible but pointed or very irregular lots should be avoided d double frontage lots and access to lots 1 double frontage lots should not be platted except that where desired along arterial streets lots may face on an interior street and back on such thoroughfares in that event a planting strip for a screen of at least 20 feet in width shall be provided along the back of the lot access may not be provided onto the arterials 2 less than 200 feet shall not in general derive access exclusively from an arterial where driveway access from an arterial may be necessary for several adjoining lots the plan commission may require that such lots be served by a combined access drive in order to limit traffic hazards on the street driveways should be designed and arranged so as to avoid requiring vehicles to back into traffic on arterials e waterbodies and watercourses if a tract being subdivided contains a water body or portion thereof lot lines shall be drawn to distribute ownership of the water body among adjacent lots the plan commission may approve an alternative plan whereby the ownership of and responsibility for safe maintenance of the water body is so placed that it will not become a local government responsibility no portion of the minimum area of lot required under this with the finished grade b monuments shall be set 1 at the intersection of all lines forming angles in the boundary of the subdivision  and 2 at the intersection of street property lines 3 at street intersections and points of tangency along street center lines c markers shall be set at all other lot corners not established by a monument d monuments shall consist of metal bars not less than onehalf inch in diameter and 30 inches in length encased in a concrete cylinder at least four inches in diameter and 30 inches in depth e markers shall consist of iron pipes or steel bars at least 16 inches long and not less than onehalf inch in diameter f all monuments and markets shall be properly set as required by 1ac 865 rule 12 prior to the time the plan commission recommends approval of the subdivider shall provide the subdivision with a complete water main supply system which shall be connected to an existing approved municipal or community water supply 1 the developer shall install adequate water facilities including fire hydrants subject to the specifications of state or local authorities all water mains shall be at least eight inches in diameter 2 the location of all fire hydrants all water supply improvements and the boundary lines of proposed districts indicated all improvements proposed to be served shall be shown on the primary plat and the cost of installing same shall be borne by the developer and included in the subdivision improvement agreement and security to be furnished by the developer b the plans for the installation of a water main supply system shall be provided by the subdivider and approved by idem upon completion of the water supply installation plans for such system as built shall be filed with the plan commission c fire hydrants shall be provided where city water supply is available fire hydrants shall be spaced no more than 800 feet part along public streets and also shall be no more than 800 feet from any residential structure fire hydrants and water mains placed on private property shall be located within dedicated easements along driveways or entrance roads and be accessible to fire department vehicles all fire hydrants installed on private property shall be the responsibility of the developer if said developer transfers ownership of the premises prior to construction of a structure on the premises he shall inform the property owner of the above requirement adequate water supply as determined by the city engineer shall be provided to all fire hydrants art 5 div 3  5 7699 storm drainage a purpose these stormwater drainage regulations are intended to minimize offsite water runoff increase onsite infiltration encourage natural filtration functions stimulate natural drainage systems and minimize offsite discharge of pollutants stormwater shall be managed by the best and most appropriate technology and environmentallysound siteplanning and engineering techniques which may include combined detention facilities porous paving and piping and swales  as well as traditional retention and detention facilities and storm sewers the following criteria shall be used in designing and evaluating the drainage system b general requirements 1 the plan commission shall not recommend for approval any plat of subdivision that does not make adequate provision for storm and flood water runoff channels or basins the applicant may be required by the plan commission to carry away by pipe or open ditch any spring or surface water that may exist either previously to or as a result of the subdivision 2 the stormwater drainage system shall be separate and independent of any sanitary sewer system 3 surface water drainage patterns shall be shown for each and every lot and block c required public sewers 1 accessibility to public storm sewers a the applicant shall install storm sewer facilities or if no outlets are within a reasonable distance adequate provision shall be made for the disposal of stormwaters subject to the specifications of the stormwater management board however in subdivisions containing lots less than 15000 square feet in area and in business and industrial districts underground storm sewer systems shall be constructed throughout the subdivisions and be conducted to an approved outfall inspection of facilities shall be conducted by the city engineer 2 design of public sewers storm sewers shall be designed in keeping with the requirement of the stormwater management board d dedication of drainage easements 1 general requirements when a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse drainage way channel or stream there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage rightofway conforming substantially to the lines of such watercourse and of such width and construction as will be adequate for the purpose wherever possible it is desirable that the drainage be maintained by an open channel with landscaped banks and adequate width for maximum potential volume of flow 2 drainage easements a where topography or other conditions are such as to make impractical the inclusion of drainage facilities within road rightsofway perpetual unobstructed easements at least 15 feet in width for drainage facilities shall be provided across property outside the road lines and with satisfactory access to the road easements shall be indicated on the plat drainage easements shall extend from the road to a natural watercourse or to other drainage facilities b when a proposed drainage system will carry water across private land outside the subdivision appropriate drainage rights must be secured and indicated on the plat c the applicant shall dedicate either in fee or by a drainage or conservation easement land on both sides of existing watercourses to a distance to be determined by the planning commission d lowlying lands along watercourses subject to flooding or overflowing during storm periods whether or not included in areas for dedication shall be preserved and retained in their natural state as drainage ways such land or lands subject to periodic flooding shall not be computed in determining the number of lots to be utilized for average density procedures nor for computing the area requirement of any lot e structures shall not be permitted in the drainage easement art 5 div 3  6 7699  a 10201 sidewalks bike trails and other linkages sidewalks and other appropriate linkages are required in all subdivisions and will be provided by the developer before any certificate of occupancy permit shall be issued 1 required improvements a sidewalks shall be included within the dedicated nonpavement right of way in a manner approved by the city engineer b curbs shall be constructed of portland cement concrete and shall conform with the adopted city standards maintained by the city engineer 2 pedestrian access the plan commission may require in order to facilitate pedestrian access from the roads to schools parks 137221 et seq  solid waste disposal ic 369301 et seq  collection and disposal of waste local option ic 369331 et seq article i  in general definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning ashes means the residue from the burning of wood coal coke and other combustible materials in homes stores institutions and industries for the purpose of cooking heating and disposing of incinerated combustible rubbish city owned tote cart means a wheeled container with engraved city logos on the side of the container city approved tote cart means a wheeled container designed to be dumped or emptied by both semi automated and fullyautomated truck equipment systems combustible rubbish means waste material capable of being burned without the use of auxiliary fuel such rubbish shall include paper rags excelsior wood bedding straw leather boxes cartons etc commercial garbage or trash means garbage or trash derived from the operation of business stores hotels or office buildings and not the result of the ordinary operation of private residences households lodging houses or apartment buildings construction wastes or debris means wastes or debris from building construction alteration or repairs and dirt from excavation unusual or special manufacturing or trade wastes or debris are also classified as construction wastes or debris garbage means all discarded and unwanted common household and kitchen wastes rubbish including but not limited to food food residues and materials necessarily used for packaging storing preparing and consuming the same and all waste materials resulting from the usual routine or domestic housekeeping including but not limited to aluminum and steel cans  glass containers  plastic containers  crockery and other containers  metal  paper of all types including newspapers books magazines and catalogs  boxes and cartons  cold ashes  furnishings and fixtures  textiles and leather  toys and recreational equipment  and similar items noncombustible rubbish consists of inorganic wastes that cannot be burned or incinerated without the use of auxiliary fuel such rubbish shall include tin cans metals mineral matter glass and crockery property cleanout means any waste debris garbage rubbish or unwanted items being placed at the curb easement or roadside for collection resulting from a structure clean out or the sale of real estate property residential change of address new resident or occupant recyclable material includes but is not limited to aluminum cans clean foil pie tins glass jars and bottles newspapers telephone books office paper catalogs magazines junk mail cardboard fiberboard and mixed paper plastic bottles plastic milk jugs plastic juice containers cereal boxes paper towel rolls empty steel and tin cans recyclables shall be interchangeable with recyclable material resident means the owner or occupant of a single family residential unit duplex or fourplex multifamily residential unit in the city scavenger means any individual who shall go from place to place within the city on any vehicle mechanical or otherwise for the purpose of collection of garbage rubbish ashes or waste materials or any such individual who shall engage in the business of collecting garbage waste material ashes or rubbish tote cart means a city approved and or owned wheeled container designed to contain garbage recyclable material and yard waste designed to be dumped or emptied by both semiautomated and fullyautomated truck equipment systems yard waste means grass clippings landscape vegetation plants trees small brush or limbs leaves and other organic garden debris  12412 cross reference definitions generally  14 secs 7027025  reserved article ii  department of sanitation footnotes  2  editors note 29 pertaining to the department of sanitation has been collection service the city garbage collection service shall serve each singlefamily residential unit and each duplex located within the city in addition the city garbage collection service shall serve fourplex multifamily residential units however garbage will not be picked up from and no fee will be charged to a multifamily residential unit larger than a fourplex to a multifamily residential unit which is part of an apartment complex or from two or more fourplexes which are adjacent to each other and which are owned by the same person or entity the fee is established as a flat minimum fee per month per unit served see fee schedule 1 senior citizens may apply for the senior citizen discount if qualified the senior citizen shall pay a flat minimum fee per month see fee schedule applications for the senior citizen discount shall be available at the utility service board office at 6071 central ave portage in 46368 an applicant shall qualify for the discount if the senior citizen provides proof that the applicant or spouse is the owner and is domiciled in a singlefamily residential unit or duplex and the applicant or spouse is 65 years or older the application for senior citizen discount shall be renewed yearly 2 a disabled person or a disabled american veteran may apply for the disabled persons discount if qualified the disabled persons shall pay a flat minimum fee per month see fee schedule applications for the disabled persons discount shall be available at the utility service board office at 6071 central ave portage in 46368 an applicant shall qualify for the discount if the disabled person provides proof that the applicant or spouse is the owner and is domiciled in a singlefamily residential unit or duplex and the applicant or spouse is disabled this shall be evidenced by approval from social security insurance ssi social security disability insurance ssdi other written verification from the social security office of the disability written verification from veterans affairs written verification from railroad police or fire disability determination letter or verification from county auditortax bill the application for disabled persons discount shall be renewed yearly the monthly garbage collection fee shall increase by $025 per month on january 1 of each year beginning in 2017  provided that a review shall be completed every three to five years to determine whether this rate increase continues to be reasonable and appropriate b the garbage collection fee shall be billed monthly in conjunction with the sanitary sewer fee the garbage collection fee shall be billed and collected by the utility service board all other costs fees fines or other related charges in the replacement of missing tote carts and in the collection of bulk items or any other yard waste  discarded materials will be collected by the clerk treasurers office the city may use all means necessary to collect and recover all past due accounts all accounts due are subject to a penalty of ten percent if not paid on or before the expiration of the pastdue date shown on the billing statement in collecting past due accounts the city shall be entitled to recover its costs of collection including reasonable attorney fees c the fees collected pursuant to this section shall be deposited in the city general fund and shall be used exclusively to defray the expenses of the department d owners of residential units which will be served by the city garbage collection service as set forth in subsection a of this section who currently have contracts with private scavengers for garbage collection may receive an exemption from the garbage collection fee for the duration of the current term of that contract all requests for exemptions shall be made to the board of public works and safety and shall be granted or denied by the board in its discretion e persons served by the city garbage collection service may have garbage collection service vacated while they are out of town garbage collection service may be vacated for a maximum period of four months per calendar year in order to have garbage collection service vacated all of the following conditions must apply 1 the customer must occupy the residential property as hisher primary residence 2 the customer must intend to return to the residential property after being out of town 3 the customer shall pay a nonrefundable vacate fee see fee schedule 4 the customer shall notify the utility service office of the time period during which garbage collection service should be vacated garbage collection service shall resume when the customer returns to the property or upon the expiration of four months whichever occurs first at that time the utility service department shall resume monthly billing for garbage collection service f each customer that prepays the entire amount owed under this article for the current year on or before january 31 of that year shall be entitled department the resident will pay monthly an additional garbage collection fee equal to onehalf of the regular garbage collection fee for each additional cityowned tote cart see fee schedule b residents shall keep the cityowned tote carts provided to them clean and in good repair all cityowned tote carts that have been damaged wear and tear will be repaired or replaced at no cost to the residential dwelling unit residents will be responsible for repairreplacement cost if a cityowned tote cart at a residential dwelling unit is damaged an excessive number of times is damaged by fire broken by abnormal means or lost see fee schedule missing cityowned tote carts require a completed police report in order to waive replacement costs c on the scheduled residential garbage pickup day all tote carts that need to be emptied of garbage or recyclable material shall to be placed at the street tote carts are to be placed three feet apart from each other from any parked vehicle on street or any other objects that may interfere with automation collection tote cart wheels and handle are placed towards house and the directional arrow points toward street all tote carts shall not be stored or placed in any area that impedes pedestrian or vehicular traffic in a public rightofway failure to follow tote cart placement requirements may delay or interrupt residential garbage collection service d all tote carts containing garbage or recyclable materials will be emptied between the hours of  am and  pm on the designated collection day all tote carts shall be set out at curbside or street on the designated collection day before  am and no earlier than noon of the day proceeding the regular collection day all tote carts shall be removed from curbside or street no later than noon on the day after the regular collection the resident shall promptly clean up and remove any scattered garbage rejected items andor recyclable material from the property before noon on the day after the scheduled date of regular collection  12412   6413 general specifications a the weekly amount of garbage to be collected from each residential dwelling unit shall be limited to a
