yard waste yard waste pickup is designed to be a service to residents with current trash collection accounts for routine maintenance of residential yards it is the responsibility of the resident to remove yard waste debris from contracted services or residential lot clearing contractors are not permitted to utilize residential city services as a means of removal for commercial work performed at any location within or outside of the city of portage city crews are not permitted to remove debris generated in either of these circumstances the city uses specialized equipment to pickup and process all yard debris there must not be any man made foreign material mixed in with the yard waste a grass clippings are highly recommended to be mulched composted or recycled by the resident to avoid disposal services by spreading grass clippings underneath shrubs or other areas this process replaces moisture and nutrients in the soil grass clippings are not to be placed in cityowned tote carts grass clippings can be brought to the street department from  am to  pm on scheduled work days residents must report to the office and show proof of residence before dropping off grass clippings grass clippings must be placed in biodegradable paper yard waste bags and be free from manmade materials yard waste bags must be placed in the designated area for grass clippings grass clippings in plastic bags will not be accepted residents who discard grass clippings for trash collection will incur a fee of $2500 for each load collected see fee schedule one load shall consist of grass clippings totaling 40 square feet or less b the city acting street department shall provide curbside collection of tree limbs and leaves to residents tree limbs are collected on a weekly basis but are subject to change as necessitated by special circumstances including but not limited to holidays special events weather conditions or equipment breakdown any changes in the collection schedule can be obtained by calling the street department monday 00 am to  pm logs limbs and branches are to be bundled andor packaged not to exceed lengths of six feet excessive limbs and branches that exceed 20 cubic yard loads at a single residential stop will result in an additional fee charged to the resident see fee schedule tree log diameter size that is larger than eight inches in diameter will result in additional costs charged to the resident see fee schedule c ideal leaf and limb pick up seasons are as follows limb pick up service starts in the beginning of april and usually ends in early august leaf pick up service starts middle of october and ends in the middle of december d to be eligible for the curbside limbleaf pickup service limbs or leaves shall be placed on the easementrightofway not in street anyone desiring limb or leaf pickup service may call the street department monday 00 am to  pm and give their name phone number and address before  pm on the date proceeding the day scheduled for their scheduled regular trash pickup e in addition to the ideal leaf and limb pickup season the street department shall provide curbside tree limb collection service for the removal of storm related tree limb damage only after a severe storm event the service shall be provided when determined necessary at the discretion of the superintendent of the street department f it is the responsibility of the resident to remove trees limbs landscape shrubbery and yard waste from contracted services or private individual lot clearing contractors are not permitted to utilize city services as a means of removal for commercial work performed at any location within or outside of the city of portage  12412   6413 appeal rights a customer who disagrees with the amount imposed under existing refuse construction waste or natural  manmade materials and if such owner shall have failed to completely comply with such notice within ten days thereafter enter upon the property and remove all of the refuse thereon situated and do such other things as may be necessary to protect the public health safety and welfare in connection with such removal  3 seek a fine for such violation in an amount not less than $5000 nor more than $250000  and 4 undertake any other action deemed to be necessary and appropriate to protect and preserve the public health safety and welfare b the remedies and penalties described in this section are cumulative and not exclusive  12412 enforcement a notice of a violation of this division may be mailed or posted as the circumstances require by any division regardless of whether such proceedings require court appearances or the filing of a lawsuit by the city attorney or other member of the city law department the city shall be entitled to recover in addition to all other rights and remedies under this division all attorneys fees costs and expenses including the expense of removing where applicable incurred in connection with enforcement of this division including such fees costs and expenses incurred on appeal if any e it is the specific intent of the common council that taxpayers of the city not be burdened with the cost sidewalk and curb policy shall be deposited into this fund the sidewalk and curb fund shall be a nonreverting fund b uses of the fund monies accumulated in the citys sidewalk and curb fund may be used for the expenses incurred in designing constructing extending and repairing sidewalks within the city monies accumulated in the fund may be used for the foregoing expenses without further appropriation  2 4798   8602 construction requirements a all sidewalks shall be constructed a minimum of five feet in width except in the case of the continuation of an already constructed sidewalk which is less than five feet but in no event to be constructed less than four feet in width if the sidewalk under construction is a gap between already constructed sidewalks in the same block it shall be constructed according to the width of the wider sidewalk adjoining to the new sidewalk five inches in thickness and one course concrete according to the specifications that follow any surface of any walk when complete shall be in conformity with the grade given by the city engineer all walks shall be laid with the inner edge on the property line unless otherwise by special permit from the common council b the subgrade shall be constructed to the required depth below the finished surface as set by the city engineer and shall be thoroughly compacted to a firm smooth surface all soft or spongy places not affording a suitable subgrade must be removed and replaced with a suitable material and compacted according to the above specifications c side forms shall be rigid and held securely in place by stakes or braces with top edge true to grade all sidewalks shall be five inches thick unless directed otherwise by the specifications herein or the city engineer the sidewalk is to have a slope of onequarter inch per foot measured across the parkway and sidewalk up from the back top of the curb consistent with surrounding lawns and walks d concrete shall consist of an approved portland cement a fine aggregate a course aggregate mixed in the proportion and manner specified in this section e all cement shall be firstclass portland cement of a reputable brand and conforming to the standard specifications of portland cement astm serial designation c150 shipment may be made in cloth sacks or paper bags plainly marked with the name of the manufacturer and the brand trademark or other acceptable distinctive marking three to six percent air entrainment shall be in accordance with astm c15 the cement shall be stored in a weathertight shelter having the floor raised off the ground fine aggregate for portland cement concrete shall consist of hard strong durable particles of the following gradation state department of transportation standard specification  aggregate size #14 no 1 or #14 no 2 screenings or crushed slag will not be permitted as a substitute for sand in concrete course aggregate shall be graded washed gravel or crushed stone in a maximum size of 112 inches consisting of clean hard durable particles free from dust dirt or other foreign substances the use of dusty or dirty stone or gravel will not be permitted the aggregate shall be stored and handled in a manner that will assure clean material free from foreign substances water used for concrete or mortar shall be clean free from oils acids alkalis or sewage all concrete shall be mixed and proportioned to give good workability with a slump between four and six inches without adding more water than six us gallons per 94pound bag of cement concrete shall show a comprehensive strength of 3000 pounds per square inch at 28 days water contained in the aggregate shall be taken into account in computing the watercement ratio f any mixer shall be of the batch type of a design and capacity meeting the approval of the city engineer scales of an approved design shall be provided for the proper proportioning of the concrete when necessary to mix by hand a watertight mortar box shall be used and the ingredients shall be turned together at least six times and more if necessary to obtain a mixture homogeneous in appearance this may be done only on written approval by the city engineer g threequarterinch bituminous premolded expansion joints shall be placed at 30foot intervals in sidewalks and between sidewalks and any abutting structures including curbs h subgrade shall be moistened before concrete is placed concrete shall be placed in successive batches with the entire width of the slab struck off approximately onehalf inch higher than the finished slab then tamped and spaded along the edges and floated to an even surface slabs shall be four feet to six feet in length the surface shall be divided by grooves at right angles to the centerline the grooves shall be between oneeighth inch and onequarter inch in width all edges to be rounded with edging tools for a onequarter inch radius the elevation of the sidewalk shall be as set by the city engineer when using transit mix trucks the first discharge of concrete from the hoppers shall be wasted to the ground if it has been entrapped in the discharge worm vane and has separated is too dry or is not of proper homogeneity i exposed surfaces of concrete shall be protected from premature drying by methods approved by the city engineer all concrete shall be kept wet for not less than seven days except that three days shall be considered sufficient if high earlystrength portland cement concrete is used see the state department of transportation standard specifications for limiting weather conditions and concrete temperatures at time of placement and other protecting and curing measures required j where driveways are to be built across the sidewalk space they shall conform to the sidewalk grade and shall be six inches in depth of the same quality and material as specified for walks k all alley crossings shall be constructed of concrete seven inches thick of the same finish and material as specified for walks and will be concave or straight as may be ordered by the city engineer l the material for all sidewalks built or repaired in the city after  may be inspected by the city engineer and he shall have the right to inspect and approve same before they are used all sidewalks made new or repaired shall be done under the supervision of the city engineer who may in his discretion inspect and report on the same before the approval and acceptance by the common council if the city engineer does not inspect approval and acceptance by the common council shall be automatic  maintenance procedures specifications a when any sidewalk within the city shall become out of repair and it is necessary to make repair consultation shall be made with the city engineer when a portion of a sidewalk block or square is damaged the entire block or square shall be removed and replaced b whenever any sidewalk shall be ordered built repaired relaid or replaced the dirt removed may be used by the city in improving the street upon which such building or repairs are being made or on streets alleys or other public places the grading of which is of the same general plan in case the city does not use the dirt the property owner may remove it together with all old material within five days after the completion of such work in case the property owner fails to do so the contractor shall proceed to remove the same and the cost thereof shall be collected as part of the cost of such improvement it shall be the duty of the contractor at all times while building repairing relaying or replacing any sidewalk to see to it that the stakes indicating the grade of the same have not been tampered with a b repair  notice to owner whenever in the opinion of the board of public works and safety any new sidewalk should be built or old sidewalks repaired in the city the board shall forthwith give notice to the owner of the abutting property or his agent if residents of the city and in case such owner or agents be nonresidents of the city the board shall serve such notice by sending a copy thereof by registered letter to such owner or agent if the address of such owner or agent be known and if such owner or agent be nonresidents and their address unknown or such real estate be vacant or unoccupied or the residence of the owner or agent be unknown then a copy of such notice shall be posted in a conspicuous place requiring such owner to build or repair the same within 45 days from the date of service of such notice in case the owner shall fail to build or repair such sidewalks after such notice has been given then the city shall proceed to build or repair such walk and the costs charges and expenses thereof shall be charged against the owner of such property and shall be collected in the same manner as assessments for street improvements  tampering with grade stake walk surface it shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person or persons to tamper with or in any way interfere with any grade stake or any sidewalk or to deface or disturb any such walk while in the process of construction c curb and gutter the installation of curbs and gutters shall be required throughout the city and shall be installed by the developer on the side of the street affronting the real estate on the streets surface the curb and gutter shall be of a design approved by the city engineer however the city engineer has the authority to waive this requirement if it is not feasible to install curbs and gutters due to a lack of adequate stormwater collection facilities specifications for construction a it shall be the obligation of any person obtaining a license for an opening or excavation in the public rightofway to backfill the excavation and replace the pavement as set forth in the following specifications 1 backfill all excavations under pavement shall be backfilled with clean granular material meeting the requirements of section 211 of the indiana state highway standard specifications each layer shall be compacted to at least 95 percent of the maximum dry density as determined by aasho t99 as modified special care shall be taken in filling around sewers water pipes gas lines etc to keep the earth at the same height on both sides to avoid shifting of the pipeline no removed paving materials or debris shall be used in backfilling the excavation unless approved by the board of public works and safety or its designee excavations not under pavement may be backfilled with virgin material removed from the excavation 2 pavement and replacement all pavement shall be replaced with a type of construction equal to or better than that which is removed and as approved by the city engineer all cuts in pavement shall be first outlined with a saw cut not less than 112 inches deep 3 concrete or brick pavements concrete used in the replacement of concrete or brick pavements not presently surfaced with an asphaltic material shall consist of sixbag concrete with seven percent air entrainment slump shall not exceed three inches coarse aggregate shall be limestone or blast furnace slag no natural gravel aggregate will be allowed brick pavement will be replaced with eight inches of concrete except in some residential streets where the city engineer may require the brick to be replaced where concrete that has an asphaltic concrete surface is replaced sixbag concrete shall be used and the concrete shall be finished flush with the surface of the existing concrete and the asphaltic surface replaced 4 hot asphaltic concrete sheet asphalt emulsified asphalt chip seals and oil mat pavements all asphaltic and oil type pavements shall be replaced with a hot asphaltic concrete surface conforming to the standard specifications hot asphaltic concrete base binder and surface of these prevailing specifications the thickness of the pavement shall be equal to that which existed but not less than three inches not less than 11 inches of coarse aggregate class a or b size no 53 shall be placed under any asphaltic concrete patch unless a concrete base is necessary asphalt placed over a concrete patch shall be cut back six inches around the concrete patch so that the two joints are offset 5 temporary patch if it is not possible due to weather conditions for the licensee to replace the pavement within 14 days following completion of work a coarse aggregate base eight inches thick and a cold asphaltic surface shall be applied and maintained as a temporary patch until permanent repairs can be made in no case shall a temporary patch be maintained more than six months before permanent repairs are made b for additional construction standards and specifications as required by the city consult with the city engineers office copies of the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines or if none then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two highways that join at or approximately at right angles  or 2 the area within which vehicles traveling upon different highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict where a highway includes two roadways at least 30 feet apart every crossing of each roadway of the divided highway by an intersecting highway is regarded as a separate intersection if the intersecting highway also includes two roadways at least 30 feet apart every crossing of two roadways of the intersecting highway is regarded as a separate intersection laned highway means a roadway which is divided into two or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic motor vehicle means 1 a vehicle except a motorized bicycle that is selfpropelled  or 2 a vehicle that is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires but not operated upon rails motorcycle means a motor vehicle with motive power having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground the term does not include a farm tractor or a motorized bicycle official time standard means standard time or daylightsavings time as may be in current use within the city official traffic control devices means a sign signal marking and device vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers pedestrian means any person afoot prima facie speed limit means the maximum speed limit a person may travel along a street or highway without committing an offense against the state or city punishable as a misdemeanor private road or driveway means every road or driveway not open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel streets it crosses  3 any plank becomes loose in a crossing constructed of planking or when such planking is broken or split  4 such crossing regardless of what material it is constructed becomes reference municipal utilities ic 81511 et seq  municipal sewage works ic 369231 et seq article i  in general division 1  utility service board creation of the utility service board there shall be created within the city of portage a board to be known as the utility service board each and every utility owned and operated by the city of portage shall be controlled by the utility service board each utility that previously had its own board shall now be controlled by a manager that answers to the utility service board the individual boards for each and every utility owned and operated by the city of portage shall be disposed of and the powers and duties of each board transferred to the utility service board on  at  am  101309 inclusion of stormwater facilities the utility service board shall by virtue of this division control any and all stormwater facilities located within the city of portage and any area serviced by the stormwater management department after  at  am the utility service board shall serve as the board of directors of the stormwater management department  101309 makeup of the utility service board the utility service board shall consist of the members of the common council of the city of portage pursuant to ic 81533a2  101309   1516   22317 reserved editors note  adopted feb 23 201 repealed which pertained to appointment of members and derived from the works in accordance with this article  secs 82288240  reserved division 2  utility service board footnotes  2  editors note  adopted nov 17 200 amended div 2 in its entirety to read as herein set out former div 2  82418244 pertained to the water reclamation board and derived from 1524 and  adopted  cross reference administration ch 2 created general authority there is hereby created in the city a board to be known as the utility service board the board shall supervise the control acquisition improvement equipment custody operation and maintenance of the portage sewage treatment works  111709 membership terms bond the composition of the board shall be as outlined in sections 823 and 824 of the portage municipal  111709 organization compensation the organization and compensation of the board shall be as outlined in sections 823 824 and 825 of the portage municipal  111709 powers and duties of the utility service board with regard to the water reclamation department a the board may establish bylaws rules and regulations for its own government with respect to all matters of custody operation administration and maintenance of the sewage treatment works it shall have all the powers and perform all the duties of the board of public works and safety and shall have full power to make all necessary construction reconstruction repairs renewals enlargements extensions or additions to the sewage treatment works and execute any and all contracts therefor b the board may enter into all contracts or agreements necessary or incidental to the performance of its duties and the execution of its powers in carrying out the provisions of this article any contract relating to the financing or the acquisition or the construction of any works or to any trust indenture authorized shall be approved by the common council c the board may employ fix the compensation and prescribe the duties of engineers architects inspectors superintendent manager collectors attorneys and such other employees as in its judgment may be necessary  provided that all compensation and all services incurred shall be paid solely from funds provided under the laws of the state the board is prohibited from binding itself or the city beyond the extent to which money shall have been or may be provided under state law d the board shall operate manage and control the works and may order and complete any extensions or improvements to the works deemed necessary for the use of any available fund or fund to be made available the board shall adopt rules and regulations for the use and operation of the works and other sewers and drains connected therewith so far as they may affect the operation of the works e all public ways or public works damaged or destroyed by the board in the performance of its duties shall be restored or repaired by the board and placed in their original condition as nearly as practical out of funds provided if requested to do so by proper authority  111709 sanitary boardestablishment a a sanitary board for the management of the citys sewage works is established pursuant to ic 369234 b the board shall consist of three members two members shall be appointed by the common council one of the members appointed by the common council must be a registered professional engineer the mayor shall serve as a member of the board and as its chairperson c each member shall serve a term of three years except that one of the initial members shall serve a term of two years and then three year terms thereafter d members shall serve without compensation except reimbursement for necessary expenses incurred by the member in the performance of official duties e each member of the board shall execute a bond in the amount of $1500000 for faithful discharge of all duties as a member of the sanitary board each bond shall be made payable to the state of indiana the treasurer of the sanitary board shall execute a bond an amount equal to the amount required for the bond required of the clerktreasurer and made payable to the state of indiana if the treasurer of the sanitary board is the clerktreasurer the clerktreasurer need not execute a separate bond from the bond already required of that office  5118 transition from utility service board the municipal sewage works is currently managed by the utility service board pursuant to section 8241 of the municipal the city of portage it is contemplated by the mayor and common council that management of the sewage works may be transferred from the utility service board to the sanitary board established under section 8245 of this division any such transfer shall occur pursuant to a separate ordinance passed and adopted by the common council until such time as the common council may adopt an ordinance transferring management of the sewage works from the utility service board to the sanitary board the utility service board shall retain exclusive custody control and management of the municipal sewage works  5118 duties a upon transfer of management as described in section 8246 of this division the sanitary board shall then have the following powers and duties 1 operate manage and control the sewage works and order any extensions or improvements the sanitary board considers necessary 2 enter into all contracts or agreements necessary or incidental to the performance of its duties and the execution of its powers under ic 36923 et seq 3 employ fix the compensation of and prescribe the duties of engineers architects inspectors superintendents managers collectors attorneys and any other employees the sanitary board considers necessary payable solely from the revenues of the sewage works 4 recommend to the legislative body just and equitable fees for the services rendered by the sewage works any such recommendation shall include the anticipated expenses for the operation and maintenance of the sewage works to justify the fees recommended the common council may establish just and equitable fees pursuant to ic 3692325 5 issue and sell bonds of the sewage works in the name of the city of portage for the improvement of the sewage works the sanitary board may not issue any bonds under this subsection until it has secured the approval of the common council the clerktreasurer shall prepare the bonds for issuance and sell them in the manner determined to be in the best interests of the municipality the bonds are a valid claims only against the sinking fund and the revenues of the sewage works 6 submit a budget to the common council on or before november 1 of each year detailing the financial needs of the sewage works for the next year the budget shall use the budget classification system prescribed by the office of the clerktreasurer upon submission of the budget the common council may approve amend or reject the budget if a budget for the sewage works is not approved on or before december 31 then the budget for the next year shall be the same as the then current years budget if during the year the sanitary board determines circumstances exist which require additional funds be appropriated and set aside from the funds of the department then the sanitary board shall submit a request to the common council describing the appropriation for which additional funds are needed the amount of the current appropriation the amount of the additional sums requested and the source of the additional sums the common council may approve reduce or reject the request  5118 finance a the revenue of the sewage works shall be kept by the clerktreasurer and shall be kept separate and aside from the other funds of the city the clerktreasurer may expend money from the funds of the sewage works only upon proper approval by the sanitary board b the rates and charges affixed by the common council for the sewage works shall be billed to users monthly by the clerktreasurer the clerktreasurer shall also include on the bills any charges due to trash and storm water services each rate and charge shall be separately listed on the bill clearly indicating the name of the rate or charge and the amount owed c upon collection of each months billing the clerktreasurer shall separate those amounts collected for the sewage works and deposit those monies into the separate funds determined by the sanitary board the clerktreasurer shall withhold from the monthly revenues collected on behalf of the sewage works a proportionate share of the costs incurred by the clerktreasurer for billing on or before october 15 of each year the clerktreasurer shall notify the sanitary board the total anticipated cost for billing for the next year and the estimated proportionate share attributable to the sanitary board the clerktreasurer shall determine the proportionate share by dividing the costs of billing by the number of boards with rates and charges on the clerktreasurers monthly billing if the sanitary board objects to the amount of billing costs attributed to it by the clerktreasurer then it may appeal to common council for a final determination d a sinking fund of the sewage works is hereby established pursuant to ic 3692321 the fund shall be used for the payment of 1 the principal of and interest on bonds issued by the sanitary board  and 2 the charges of banks or trust companies for making payment of the principal or interest the net revenues of the sewage works after the payment of the reasonable expense of operation repair and maintenance of the works shall be pledged to the sinking fund  5118 coordination with common council it is the desire of the common council to have a close working relationship with the sanitary board to better serve the residents of the city of portage the common council shall meet as a committee of the whole at least once per month at a time determined by the committee the superintendent of the sewage works shall appear and provide a report to the committee of the activities of the sewage works for the preceding month and anticipated activities of the upcoming month the committee may inquire with the superintendent as to the costs and expenses and related matters of the activities described the committee may make recommendations to the superintendent on sewage works expenditures  5118 secs 82508255  reserved division 3  connections definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this division shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning bod denoting biochemical oxygen demand means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees celsius expressed in milligrams per liter building sewer means the extension of the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage garbage means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation cooking and dispensing of food and from the handling storage and sale of produce industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes trade or business as distinct from sanitary sewage inspector means the person duly authorized by the board to inspect and approve the installation of building sewers and connection to the public sewer system natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse pond ditch lake or other body of surfacewater or groundwater person means any individual firm company association society corporation or group ph means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of oxygen ions in grams per liter of solution properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers with no particle greater than onehalf inch in any dimension public sewer means a sewer which is on public property and controlled by public authority sanitary building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of any sanitary drainage system inside the walls of any building which receives the discharge from soil or waste stacks and branches and conveys the same to a point three feet outside the building walls where it connects with its respective building sewer sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwaters groundwaters and surface waters are not intentionally admitted sewage means a combination of the watercarried wastes from residences business buildings institutions and industrial establishments together with such stormwaters groundwaters and surface waters as may be present sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage sewage works means all facilities for collection pumping treating and disposing of sewage sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage sludge means any discharge of water sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24hour concentration or flows during normal operation storm drain means a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and drainage but excludes sewage and industrial wastes other than unpolluted cooling water superintendent means the superintendent of the municipal sewage works of the city suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water sewage or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs either continuously or intermittently aq sw cross reference definitions generally  14 prohibited deposits on property it shall be unlawful for any person to place deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any human or animal excrement garbage or other objectionable waste a discharge into natural outlet it shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any sewage or other polluted waters except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this division b prohibited facilities it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy privy vault cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage with the exception of a septic tank and absorption field c toilet facilities required  connection to sewers the owner of each house building or property used for human occupancy employment recreation or other purposes situated within the city and abutting on any street alley or rightofway in which there is installed a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this division within 90 days after the date of official notice to do so provided that such sewer is within 300 feet of the property line d private sewage systems  permit requirements a where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available under the provisions of section 8260 the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this division b before any commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the secretarytreasurer of the board the application for such permit shall be filed with the secretarytreasurer of the board on a form furnished by the board which applicant shall supplement by any plans specifications and other information deemed necessary to the board the sum of $3500 as permit and inspection fee shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed c a permit for private sewage disposal systems shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the designated representative of the board such representative shall be allowed to inspect any stage of construction and in any event the applicant for the permit shall notify the representative when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered the inspection shall be made within 24 hours of the receipt of notice by such representative but within regular working hours d the type capacity location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the current state department of health bulletins nos se 8 and se 13 except as provided in this section copies of such bulletins nos se 8 and se 13 are incorporated by reference as part of this section and two copies are filed in the offices of the board for public inspection no septic tank shall be permitted to discharge into any natural outlet no permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities except as noted below 1 the board shall issue permits for singlefamily installation of septic tanks in those areas having slight or moderate soil limitations as classified by the soil conservation service such shall be issued only for a tank size of at least a 1000gallon capacity with a field absorption system of at least 1000 square feet of absorption area minimum lot area in such cases shall be one acre of suitable soils andor usable terrain for the installation of such systems and have sufficient area for an additional 1000 square feet of absorption field if required 2 the board shall not issue permits for individual septic tank installations for singlefamily residences in areas having soil classified as severe because of slow permeability except for those soils in this classification having moderately welldrained characteristics as noted by the soil conservation service such permits for septic tank installations in these areas shall require a septic tank containing a minimum capacity of 1000 gallons and a minimum field absorption system of 2000 square feet of absorption area each lot shall contain a minimum of one acre of suitable soils andor usable terrain for the installation of such systems and have sufficient area for the additional 2000 square feet of absorption field if required 3 the board shall issue permits for the installation of septic tanks for multifamily residences in those areas having slight or moderate soil limitations as classified by the soil conservation service duplex living units shall be required to have the one acre minimum lot area required for a singlefamily residence for the first unit and an additional onehalf acre of lot area for the second unit each living unit shall have its own septic tank and absorption field in accordance with the requirements for singlefamily residences any living units in addition to the original two shall have an additional lot size of 13500 square feet per additional unit and each additional unit shall have a 1000 gallon septic tank and 1000 square foot absorption field sufficient lot size shall be available for the installation of an additional 1000 square foot absorption field per living unit 4 the board shall not issue permits for individual septic tank installations for multifamily residences in those areas having soil classified as severe because of slow permeability except for those soils in this classification having a moderately welldrained characteristic as noted by the soil conservation service such permits in these areas shall require that duplex living units have a minimum lot area of two acres each living unit shall have its own septic tank minimum capacity of 1000 gallons and absorption field minimum 2000 square feet any living units in addition to the original two shall have an additional lot size of one acre per additional unit and each such additional unit shall have a 1000 gallon septic tank and 2000 square foot absorption field sufficient lot area shall be available for the installation of an additional 2000 square feet of absorption field for each unit if required 5 the board shall issue permits for the installation of septic tanks and field absorption areas for commercial and industrial construction in those areas having slight or moderate soil limitations as classified by the soil conservation service using the estimated percolation rates currently established by the soil conservation service in conjunction with the tables to be found in the currently used state department of health bulletin se 13 commercial and industrial sites in all cases shall have sufficient area for the installation of a second absorption field if required 6 permits for the installation of septic tank and field absorption systems for commercial or industrial construction shall not be issued by the board in those areas with soils classified as having severe properties because of slow permeability and poor drainage characteristics as noted by the soil conservation service 7 in those cases where percolation tests are utilized as the basis for permit issuance such tests shall be conducted and submitted by a registered engineer andor land surveyor whose stamp shall be affixed to a data sheet or sheets such tests shall be conducted as outlined in the se 8 bulletin of the state department of health currently in use where tests are submitted for specific lots there shall be a minimum of three test holes and they shall be placed a minimum of 50 feet from any other test hole and all tests shall be conducted in the area designated for the installation of the disposal field any such test results with absorption rates greater than 60 minutes per inch shall not be acceptable e at such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system as provided above a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this division and any septic tanks and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material except as noted in this section f the owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage facilities in a sanitary manner at all times at no expense to the city g no statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer h when a public sewer becomes available the building sewer shall be connected to such sewer within 60 days and the private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bankrun gravel or dirt except as noted in this section i where previously used for accommodating rainwater andor groundwater collected by drain tiles around foundation footings the homeowner may elect to utilize the private sewage disposal system for the disposal of such uncontaminated water only such usage will be confined to the use of structurally sound reinforced concrete or steel tanks with integral covers andor distribution boxes together with the field tile drainage system j inspection fees an inspection fee of $5000 per inspection visit shall be materials building sanitary sewer material astm asbestoscement sewer pipe c644 c428 and c500 clay sewer pipe c200 c301 and c425 cast iron sewer pipe a74 pvc plastic pipe d1784 and d3034 c all of the above pipe and any other pipe material that may be considered henceforth shall meet the following requirements 1 inside diameters shall be a full six inches 2 minimum crushing strength shall be 1500 pounds per lineal foot 3 asbestoscement shall contain not more than one percent uncombined calcium hydroxide 4 the pipe and fittings shall be capable of withstanding the action of a motor device sewer cleaner or rotorooter without damage 5 pvc plastic pipe shall meet the requirements of astm standard d1784 rigid poly vinyl chloride and chlorinated poly vinyl chloride compounds and astm standard d3034 sdr 35 type psm poly vinyl chloride pvc sewer pipe and fittings latest revisions pipe and fitting markings shall include the appropriate astm designations and cell classification numbers 12454b or 12454c or other approved classifications pipe and fittings not so marked will be rejected standard lengths shall be ten feet 1212 feet and 20 feet 6 no building sewer shall be less than six inches inside diameter and shall be continued undiminished in size from the building drain to the street sewer and in no case shall it be smaller 7 building sewers shall be set at the minimum grade outlined below diameter of building sewer inches minimum grade in feet per 1000 6 60 8 40 10 26 12 22 14 16 15 14 d joints and connections shall be watertight and capable of meeting the water or air tests specified in this code the joints shall also be capable of holding a tenfoot head of water for 96 hours at a fivedegree deflection without leakage 1 caulked joints caulked joints for cast iron bellandspigot pipe shall be firmly packed with oakum andor hemp and filled with molten lead not less than oneinch deep and not to extend more than oneeighthinch below rim of hub no paint varnish or other coatings shall be permitted on the jointing material until after the joint has been tested and approved 2 cast iron rubber ring joint a rubber ring joint meeting asa 2111 for type ii and type iii pipe shall be permissible 3 clay pipe joints all clay pipe joints shall meet the regulations of astm c425 4 asbestoscement joints all joints shall be made with an asbestoscement or plastic coupling and two rubber sealing rings having a uniform solid cross section and conforming to astm d1869 the rings shall be contained in recessed grooves and the joint shall be designed to maintain compression of the rings under maximum differential loading the joint shall be so designed that the coupling will automatically be centered on joint 5 pvc plastic pipe joints pvc plastic lengths shall be joined utilizing elastomeric gaskets as referenced in d3034 and meeting the requirements of astm standard d3212 joints for drain and sewer plastic pipes using flexible elastomeric seals pvc plastic pipe shall be so constructed that the initial internal vertical diameter does not decrease by more than five percent in order to provide the complete hydraulic carrying capacity conceived by the design engineer and to obtain the joint performance at five percent maximum diametric deflection as specified in 74 of d3212 pvc plastic pipe shall be installed in full compliance with the recommended practice for underground installation of flexible thermoplastic sewer pipe astm standard d2321 in addition to the construction and testing procedures the contractor shall be required to install the pipe in such a manner so that the diametric deflection of the pipe shall not exceed five percent and the materials surrounding the pipe shall be compacted to the required standard proctor densities outlined in d2321 the area requiring compaction shall include the bed and sidefill material and also the material placed above the pipe for a distance of 12 inches over the top of the pipe 6 paunch manure hair and fleshings entrails and paper dishes cups milk containers etc either whole or ground by garbage grinders d no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following substances materials waters or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the superintendent that such wastes can harm either the sewers sewage treatment process or equipment or have an adverse effect on the receiving stream or can otherwise endanger life limb public property or constitute a nuisance in forming his opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes the superintendent will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to the flows and velocities in the sewers materials of construction of the sewers nature of the sewage treatment process capacity of the sewage treatment plant degree of the treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant and other pertinent factors the substances prohibited are 1 any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees fahrenheit 65 degrees celsius  2 any water or waste containing fats wax grease or oils whether emulsified or not in excess of 100 mgl or containing substances which subsection d of this section and which in the judgment of the superintendent may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works processes equipment or receiving waters or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance the superintendent may 1 reject the wastes  2 require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers  3 require control over the quantities and rates of discharge  andor 4 require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges under the provisions of subsection j of this section if the superintendent permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows the design and installation of the plans and the equipment shall be subject to the review and accessible at all times i all measurements tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this division shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of standard methods for the examination of water and waste water published by the american public health association and shall be determined at the control manhole if no special manhole has been required the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which a building sewer is connected sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life limb and property the particular analysis involved will determine whether a 24hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken normally but not always bod and suspended solids analyses are obtained from 24hour composites of all outfalls where phs are determined from periodic grab samples j no statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or ordinances industrial user means any nongovernmental user of publiclyowned treatment works identified in the standard industrial classification manual 197 office of management and budget as amended and supplemented under the following divisions 1 division a agriculture forestry and fishing  2 division b mining  3 division d manufacturing  4 division e transportation communications electric gas and sanitary services  and 5 division i services any user in these divisions may be excluded if it is determined that it will introduce only segregated domestic wastes or wastes from sanitary conveniences only industrial waste means all waste originating from an industrial user ie process water cooling water and cleanup water but excluding segregated domestic wastes or wastes from sanitary conveniences local sewer or lateral sewer means a public sewer being a part of collection system lying in the public property or easements to serve users major contributing industry means an industrial user of the publiclyowned treatment works that 1 has a flow of 50000 gallons or more per average work day  2 has a flow greater than five percent of the flow carried by the municipal system receiving the wastes  3 has in its waste a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in the standards issued under section 308a of the federal water pollution control act of 197 as amended  and 4 is found by the permit issuance authority in connection with the issuance of the npdes permit to the municipal system receiving the waste to have significant impact either singly or in combination with other contributing industries on that treatment works or upon the quality of effluent from that treatment works normal domestic strength sewage means a waste water containing the following maximum concentrations of the following pollutants bod 5  260 mgl total suspended solids 200 mgl ammonia nitrogen 33 mgl total phosphorus 10 mgl as p npdes permit means the national pollutant discharge elimination system npdes being the system for issuing conditioning and denying permits for the discharge of pollutants from point sources into navigable waters the contiguous zone and the oceans by the administrator of the environmental protection agency pursuant to sections 402 and 405 of the federal water pollution control act as amended public law 92500 33 usc 1251 et seq operation and maintenance costs means all costs incidental to the operation and maintenance of the sewer system including replacement costs replacement means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment accessories or appurtenances which are necessary during the service life of the treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works are designed and constructed the term operation and maintenance includes replacement sanitary sewage means the waste from water closets urinals lavatories sinks bathtubs showers household laundries basement drains garage floor drains bars soda fountains refrigerator drips drinking fountains and stable floor drains user charge means the charge levied on user of the treatment works for the cost and operation and maintenance of such works  reserved division 5  nondelegated pretreatment program footnotes  3  editors note  adopted  amended div 5 in its entirety and for purposes of classification and at the editors discretion these provisions have been included as  8220182213 former div 5  8220182215 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from  adopted  and  adopted feb 5 2008 general provisions a purpose and policy this division sets forth uniform requirements for users of the publicly owned treatment works for the city of portage and enables the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws including the clean water act 33 united states usc section 1251 et seq and the general pretreatment regulations 40 cfr part 403 the objectives of this division are 1 to prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned treatment works that will interfere with its operation  2 to prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned treatment works that will pass publicly owned treatment works inadequately treated into receiving waters or otherwise be incompatible with the publicly owned treatment works  3 to protect both publicly owned treatment works personnel who may be affected by wastewater and sludge in the course of their employment and the general public  4 to promote reuse and recycling of industrial wastewater and sludge from the publicly owned treatment works  5 to enable the city to comply with its national pollutant discharge elimination system permit conditions sludge use and disposal requirements and any other federal or state laws to which the publicly owned treatment works is subject  6 to improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewaters and sludge from the system  7 to empower the investigation and abatement of violations of this division and provide for the establishment and enforcement of standards rules and regulations and the authority to take samples and conduct tests and establish the right of entry  8 to establish authority for user reporting  9 to establish the persons liable for violations and provide for fines for violation of the provisions of this division and provide just and adequate means by which this division may be enforced  10 to regulate the direct and indirect discharges to the municipal wastewater system issuance of discharge permits and of general requirements to all users  and 11 to provide for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the pretreatment program established herein this division shall apply to all users of the publicly owned treatment works the division authorizes the issuance of individual wastewater discharge permits  provides for monitoring compliance and enforcement activities  establishes administrative review procedures  requires user reporting  and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein b administration except as otherwise provided herein the pretreatment coordinator andor the superintendent shall administer implement and enforce the provisions of this division any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the pretreatment coordinator andor the superintendent may be delegated by the pretreatment coordinator andor the superintendent to a duly authorized city employee c abbreviations the following abbreviations when used in this division shall have the designated meanings bod  biochemical oxygen demand bmp  best management practice bmr  baseline monitoring report cbod  carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand cfr  federal regulations ciu  categorical industrial user cod  chemical oxygen demand erg  enforcement response guide epa  us environmental protection agency gpd  gallons per day idem  indiana department of environmental management iu  industrial user iwp  industrial waste permit mgl  milligrams per liter npdes  national pollutant discharge elimination system nsciu  nonsignificant categorical industrial user o&m  operation and maintenance potw  publicly owned treatment works sic  standard industrial classification siu  significant industrial user snc  significant noncompliance during a calendar day where daily maximum limits are expressed in units of mass the daily discharge is the total mass discharged over the course of the day where daily maximum limits are expressed in promulgated by the us epa in accordance with subsections 307b and c of the act which applies to users this term includes prohibitive discharge limits established pursuant to 40 cfr 4035 49 new source a any building structure facility or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under subsection 307c of the act that will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section provided that 1 the building structure facility or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located  or 2 the building structure facility or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source  or 3 the production or wastewater generating processes of the building structure facility or installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site in determining whether these are substantially independent factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source will be considered b construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building structure facility or installation meeting the criteria of subsections a1 or a2 above but otherwise alters replaces or adds to existing process or production equipment c construction of a new source as defined under this subsection has commenced if the owner or operator has 1 begun or caused to begin as part of a continuous onsite construction program i any placement assembly or installation of facilities or equipment  or ii significant site preparation work including clearing excavation or removal of existing buildings structures or facilities which is necessary for the placement assembly or installation of new source facilities or equipment  or 2 entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss and contracts for feasibility engineering and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this subsection 50 nh3n ammonia as nitrogen a parameter found in wastewater facilities users shall provide wastewater treatment as necessary to comply with this division and shall achieve compliance with all categorical pretreatment standards state and local limits and the prohibitions set out in section 82202 of this division within the time limitations specified by us epa the state or the pretreatment coordinator andor superintendent whichever is more stringent any facilities necessary for compliance shall be provided operated and maintained at the users expense detailed plans describing such facilities and operating procedures shall be submitted to the control authority and pretreatment coordinator andor superintendent for review and shall be acceptable to the control authority pretreatment coordinator andor superintendent before such facilities are constructed or modified the review of such plans and operating procedures shall in no way relieve the user from the responsibility of modifying such facilities as necessary to produce a discharge acceptable to the city under the provisions of this division b additional pretreatment measures 1 whenever deemed necessary the pretreatment coordinator andor superintendent may require users to restrict their discharge during peak flow periods designate that certain wastewater be discharged only into specific sewers relocate andor consolidate points of discharge separate sewage waste streams from industrial waste streams and such other conditions as may be necessary to protect the potw and determine the users compliance with the requirements of this division 2 the pretreatment coordinator andor superintendent may require any person discharging into the potw to install and maintain on their property and at their expense a suitable storage and flowcontrol facility to ensure equalization of flow an individual wastewater discharge permit may be issued solely for flow equalization 3 establishments involved in the preparation of food for commercial purposes shall provide grease interceptors or traps grease oil and sand interceptors shall be provided by other users when deemed necessary by the pretreatment coordinator for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts or any flammable wastes sand or other harmful ingredients all interceptors shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for inspection documentation of one year of maintenanceservice records shall be available onsite for review inspections will be performed at a minimum of two times a year by the pretreatment coordinator or a representative of the potw grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature they shall be of substantial construction watertight and equipped with easily removable covers that shall be gastight and watertight and capable of the maximum flow rate of the pipe installed therein this is to be provided unless an alternate removal method is approved in writing by the pretreatment coordinator andor superintendent 4 users with the potential to discharge flammable substances may be required to install and maintain an approved combustible gas detection meter c accidental dischargeslug discharge control plans asdc the pretreatment coordinator andor superintendent shall evaluate whether each siu needs an accidental dischargeslug discharge control plan or other action to control slug discharges the pretreatment coordinator andor superintendent may require any user to develop submit for approval and implement such a plan or take such other action that may be necessary to control slug discharges an accidental dischargeslug discharge control plan shall address at a minimum the following 1 description of discharge practices including nonroutine batch discharges  2 description of stored chemicals  3 procedures for immediately notifying the pretreatment coordinator andor superintendent of any accidental or slug discharge as required by subsection 82204f of this division  and 4 procedures to prevent adverse impact from any accidental or slug discharge such procedures include but are not limited to inspection and maintenance of storage areas handling and transfer of materials loading and unloading operations control of plant site runoff worker training building of containment structures or equipment measures for containing toxic organic pollutants including solvents andor measures and equipment for emergency response the asdc plan shall be updated annually and submitted to the pretreatment coordinator no later than february 1 of each calendar year said plan shall be accompanied by a compliance affidavit stating that said plan has been reviewed and updated and shall be signed by the highest ranking official at the users location  4709 reporting requirements a baseline monitoring reports 1 within either 180 days after the effective date of a categorical pretreatment standard or the final
